of brook they pass away; 6:16 which are blackish by reason of the
ice, and wherein the snow is hid: 6:17 what time they wax warm, they
vanish: when it is hot, they are consum out of their place.

6:18 the path of their way are turn aside; they go to nothing, and
perish.

6:19 the troop of tema looked, the compani of sheba wait for
them.

6:20 they were confound becaus they had hoped; they came thither,
and were ashamed.

6:21 for now ye are nothing; ye see my cast down, and are afraid.

6:22 did I say, bring unto me? or, give a reward for me of your
substance?  6:23 or, deliv me from the enemy' hand? or, redeem me
from the hand of the mighty?  6:24 teach me, and I will hold my
tongue: and caus me to understand wherein I have erred.

6:25 how forcibl are right words! but what doth your argu reprove?
6:26 Do ye imagin to reprov words, and the speech of one that is
desperate, which are as wind?  6:27 yea, ye overwhelm the fatherless,
and ye dig a pit for your friend.

6:28 now therefor be content, look upon me; for it is evid unto
y if I lie.

6:29 return, I pray you, let it not be iniquity; yea, return again, my
right is in it.

6:30 Is there iniqu in my tongue? cannot my tast discern perverse
things?  7:1 Is there not an appoint time to man upon earth? are not
hi day also like the day of an hireling?  7:2 As a servant
earnestli desireth the shadow, and as an hirel looketh for the
reward of hi work: 7:3 So am I made to possess month of vanity, and
wearisom night are appoint to me.

7:4 when I lie down, I say, when shall I arise, and the night be gone?
and I am full of toss to and fro unto the dawn of the day.

7:5 My flesh is cloth with worm and clod of dust; my skin is
broken, and becom loathsome.

7:6 My day are swifter than a weaver' shuttle, and are spent without
hope.

7:7 O rememb that my life is wind: mine eye shall no more see good.

7:8 the eye of him that hath seen me shall see me no more: thine eyes
ar upon me, and I am not.

7:9 As the cloud is consum and vanisheth away: so he that goeth down
to the grave shall come up no more.

7:10 He shall return no more to hi house, neither shall hi place
know him ani more.

7:11 therefor I will not refrain my mouth; I will speak in the
anguish of my spirit; I will complain in the bitter of my soul.

7:12 Am I a sea, or a whale, that thou settest a watch over me?  7:13
when I say, My bed shall comfort me, my couch shall eas my
complaints; 7:14 then thou scarest me with dreams, and terrifiest me
through visions: 7:15 So that my soul chooseth strangling, and death
rath than my life.

7:16 I loath it; I would not live alway: let me alone; for my days
ar vanity.

7:17 what is man, that thou shouldest magnifi him? and that thou
shouldest set thine heart upon him?  7:18 and that thou shouldest
visit him everi morning, and tri him everi moment?  7:19 how long wilt
thou not depart from me, nor let me alon till I swallow down my
spittle?  7:20 I have sinned; what shall I do unto thee, O thou
preserv of men?  whi hast thou set me as a mark against thee, so
that I am a burden to myself?  7:21 and whi dost thou not pardon my
transgression, and take away my iniquity? for now shall I sleep in the
dust; and thou shalt seek me in the morning, but I shall not be.

8:1 then answer bildad the shuhite, and said, 8:2 how long wilt thou
speak these things? and how long shall the word of thi mouth be like
a strong wind?  8:3 doth god pervert judgment? or doth the almighty
pervert justice?  8:4 If thi children have sin against him, and he
hav cast them away for their transgression; 8:5 If thou wouldest seek
unto god betimes, and make thi supplic to the almighty; 8:6 if
thou wert pure and upright; sure now he would awak for thee, and
mak the habit of thi righteous prosperous.

8:7 though thi begin wa small, yet thi latter end should greatly
increase.

8:8 for enquire, I pray thee, of the former age, and prepar thyself
to the search of their fathers: 8:9 (for we are but of yesterday, and
know nothing, becaus our day upon earth are a shadow:) 8:10 shall
not they teach thee, and tell thee, and utter word out of their
heart?  8:11 can the rush grow up without mire? can the flag grow
without water?  8:12 whilst it is yet in hi greenness, and not cut
down, it withereth befor ani other herb.

8:13 So are the path of all that forget god; and the hypocrite' hope
shal perish: 8:14 whose hope shall be cut off, and whose trust shall
b a spider' web.

8:15 He shall lean upon hi house, but it shall not stand: he shall
hold it fast, but it shall not endure.

8:16 He is green befor the sun, and hi branch shooteth forth in his
garden.

8:17 hi root are wrap about the heap, and seeth the place of
stones.

8:18 If he destroy him from hi place, then it shall deni him, saying,
i have not seen thee.

8:19 behold, thi is the joy of hi way, and out of the earth shall
oth grow.

8:20 behold, god will not cast away a perfect man, neither will he
help the evil doers: 8:21 till he fill thi mouth with laughing, and
thi lip with rejoicing.

8:22 they that hate thee shall be cloth with shame; and the dwelling
plac of the wick shall come to nought.

9:1 then job answer and said, 9:2 I know it is so of a truth: but
how should man be just with god?  9:3 If he will contend with him, he
cannot answer him one of a thousand.

9:4 He is wise in heart, and mighti in strength: who hath hardened
himself against him, and hath prospered?  9:5 which removeth the
mountains, and they know not: which overturneth them in hi anger.

9:6 which shaketh the earth out of her place, and the pillar thereof
tremble.

9:7 which commandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the
stars.

9:8 which alon spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves
of the sea.

9:9 which maketh arcturus, orion, and pleiades, and the chamber of
th south.

9:10 which doeth great thing past find out; yea, and wonders
without number.

9:11 lo, he goeth by me, and I see him not: he passeth on also, but i
perc him not.

9:12 behold, he taketh away, who can hinder him? who will say unto
him, what doest thou?  9:13 If god will not withdraw hi anger, the
proud helper do stoop under him.

9:14 how much less shall I answer him, and choos out my word to
reason with him?  9:15 whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not
answer, but I would make supplic to my judge.

9:16 If I had called, and he had answer me; yet would I not believe
that he had hearken unto my voice.

9:17 for he breaketh me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds
without cause.

9:18 He will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with
bitterness.

9:19 If I speak of strength, lo, he is strong: and if of judgment, who
shal set me a time to plead?  9:20 If I justifi myself, mine own
mouth shall condemn me: if I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me
perverse.

9:21 though I were perfect, yet would I not know my soul: I would
despis my life.

9:22 thi is one thing, therefor I said it, He destroyeth the perfect
and the wicked.

9:23 If the scourg slay suddenly, he will laugh at the trial of the
innocent.

9:24 the earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the
fac of the judg thereof; if not, where, and who is he?  9:25 now
mi day are swifter than a post: they flee away, they see no good.

9:26 they are pass away as the swift ships: as the eagl that
hasteth to the prey.

9:27 If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leav off my
heaviness, and comfort myself: 9:28 I am afraid of all my sorrows, i
know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.

9:29 If I be wicked, whi then labour I in vain?  9:30 If I wash myself
with snow water, and make my hand never so clean; 9:31 yet shalt thou
plung me in the ditch, and mine own cloth shall abhor me.

9:32 for he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, and we
should come togeth in judgment.

9:33 neither is there ani daysman betwixt us, that might lay hi hand
upon us both.

9:34 let him take hi rod away from me, and let not hi fear terrify
me: 9:35 then would I speak, and not fear him; but it is not so with
me.

10:1 My soul is weari of my life; I will leav my complaint upon
myself; I will speak in the bitter of my soul.

10:2 I will say unto god, Do not condemn me; shew me wherefor thou
contendest with me.

10:3 Is it good unto thee that thou shouldest oppress, that thou
shouldest despis the work of thine hands, and shine upon the counsel
of the wicked?  10:4 hast thou eye of flesh? or seest thou as man
seeth?  10:5 are thi day as the day of man? are thi year as man's
days, 10:6 that thou enquirest after mine iniquity, and searchest
aft my sin?  10:7 thou knowest that I am not wicked; and there is
non that can deliv out of thine hand.

10:8 thine hand have made me and fashion me togeth round about;
yet thou dost destroy me.

10:9 remember, I beseech thee, that thou hast made me as the clay; and
wilt thou bring me into dust again?  10:10 hast thou not pour me out
a milk, and curdl me like cheese?  10:11 thou hast cloth me with
skin and flesh, and hast fenc me with bone and sinews.

10:12 thou hast grant me life and favour, and thi visit hath
preserv my spirit.

10:13 and these thing hast thou hid in thine heart: I know that this
i with thee.

10:14 If I sin, then thou markest me, and thou wilt not acquit me from
min iniquity.

10:15 If I be wicked, woe unto me; and if I be righteous, yet will i
not lift up my head. I am full of confusion; therefor see thou mine
affliction; 10:16 for it increaseth. thou huntest me as a fierc lion:
and again thou shewest thyself marvel upon me.

10:17 thou renewest thi wit against me, and increasest thine
indign upon me; chang and war are against me.

10:18 wherefor then hast thou brought me forth out of the womb? oh
that I had given up the ghost, and no eye had seen me!  10:19 I should
hav been as though I had not been; I should have been carri from
th womb to the grave.

10:20 are not my day few? ceas then, and let me alone, that I may
tak comfort a little, 10:21 befor I go whenc I shall not return,
even to the land of dark and the shadow of death; 10:22 A land of
darkness, as dark itself; and of the shadow of death, without any
order, and where the light is as darkness.

11:1 then answer zophar the naamathite, and said, 11:2 should not
th multitud of word be answered? and should a man full of talk be
justified?  11:3 should thi lie make men hold their peace? and when
thou mockest, shall no man make thee ashamed?  11:4 for thou hast
said, My doctrin is pure, and I am clean in thine eyes.

11:5 but oh that god would speak, and open hi lip against thee; 11:6
and that he would shew thee the secret of wisdom, that they are
doubl to that which is! know therefor that god exacteth of thee less
than thine iniqu deserveth.

11:7 canst thou by search find out god? canst thou find out the
almighti unto perfection?  11:8 It is as high as heaven; what canst
thou do? deeper than hell; what canst thou know?  11:9 the measure
thereof is longer than the earth, and broader than the sea.

11:10 If he cut off, and shut up, or gather together, then who can
hind him?  11:11 for he knoweth vain men: he seeth wicked also;
wil he not then consid it?  11:12 for vain men would be wise,
though man be born like a wild ass' colt.

11:13 If thou prepar thine heart, and stretch out thine hand toward
him; 11:14 If iniqu be in thine hand, put it far away, and let not
wicked dwell in thi tabernacles.

11:15 for then shalt thou lift up thi face without spot; yea, thou
shalt be stedfast, and shalt not fear: 11:16 becaus thou shalt forget
thi misery, and rememb it as water that pass away: 11:17 and thine
ag shall be clearer than the noonday: thou shalt shine forth, thou
shalt be as the morning.

11:18 and thou shalt be secure, becaus there is hope; yea, thou shalt
dig about thee, and thou shalt take thi rest in safety.

11:19 also thou shalt lie down, and none shall make thee afraid; yea,
mani shall make suit unto thee.

11:20 but the eye of the wick shall fail, and they shall not
escape, and their hope shall be as the give up of the ghost.

12:1 and job answer and said, 12:2 No doubt but ye are the people,
and wisdom shall die with you.

12:3 but I have understand as well as you; I am not inferior to
you: yea, who knoweth not such thing as these?  12:4 I am as one
mock of hi neighbour, who calleth upon god, and he answereth him:
th just upright man is laugh to scorn.

12:5 He that is readi to slip with hi feet is as a lamp despis in
th thought of him that is at ease.

12:6 the tabernacl of robber prosper, and they that provok god are
secure; into whose hand god bringeth abundantly.

12:7 but ask now the beasts, and they shall teach thee; and the fowls
of the air, and they shall tell thee: 12:8 Or speak to the earth, and
it shall teach thee: and the fish of the sea shall declar unto
thee.

12:9 who knoweth not in all these that the hand of the lord hath
wrought this?  12:10 In whose hand is the soul of everi live thing,
and the breath of all mankind.

12:11 doth not the ear tri words? and the mouth tast hi meat?  12:12
with the ancient is wisdom; and in length of day understanding.

12:13 with him is wisdom and strength, he hath counsel and
understanding.

12:14 behold, he breaketh down, and it cannot be built again: he
shutteth up a man, and there can be no opening.

12:15 behold, he withholdeth the waters, and they dri up: also he
sendeth them out, and they overturn the earth.

12:16 with him is strength and wisdom: the deceiv and the deceiver
ar his.

12:17 He leadeth counsellor away spoiled, and maketh the judges
fools.

12:18 He looseth the bond of kings, and girdeth their loin with a
girdle.

12:19 He leadeth princ away spoiled, and overthroweth the mighty.

12:20 He removeth away the speech of the trusty, and taketh away the
understand of the aged.

12:21 He poureth contempt upon princes, and weakeneth the strength of
th mighty.

12:22 He discovereth deep thing out of darkness, and bringeth out to
light the shadow of death.

12:23 He increaseth the nations, and destroyeth them: he enlargeth the
nations, and straiteneth them again.

12:24 He taketh away the heart of the chief of the peopl of the
earth, and causeth them to wander in a wilder where there is no
way.

12:25 they grope in the dark without light, and he maketh them to
stagg like a drunken man.

13:1 lo, mine eye hath seen all this, mine ear hath heard and
understood it.

13:2 what ye know, the same do I know also: I am not inferior unto
you.

13:3 sure I would speak to the almighty, and I desir to reason with
god.

13:4 but ye are forger of lies, ye are all physician of no value.

13:5 O that ye would altogeth hold your peace! and it should be your
wisdom.

13:6 hear now my reasoning, and hearken to the plead of my lips.

13:7 will ye speak wickedli for god? and talk deceit for him?
13:8 will ye accept hi person? will ye contend for god?  13:9 Is it
good that he should search you out? or as one man mocketh another, do
y so mock him?  13:10 He will sure reprov you, if ye do secretly
accept persons.

13:11 shall not hi excel make you afraid? and hi dread fall
upon you?  13:12 your remembr are like unto ashes, your bodi to
bodi of clay.

13:13 hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on
m what will.

13:14 wherefor do I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in
min hand?  13:15 though he slay me, yet will I trust in him: but i
wil maintain mine own way befor him.

13:16 He also shall be my salvation: for an hypocrit shall not come
befor him.

13:17 hear dilig my speech, and my declar with your ears.

13:18 behold now, I have order my cause; I know that I shall be
justified.

13:19 who is he that will plead with me? for now, if I hold my tongue,
i shall give up the ghost.

13:20 onli do not two thing unto me: then will I not hide myself from
thee.

13:21 withdraw thine hand far from me: and let not thi dread make me
afraid.

13:22 then call thou, and I will answer: or let me speak, and answer
th me.

13:23 how mani are mine iniqu and sins? make me to know my
transgress and my sin.

13:24 wherefor hidest thou thi face, and holdest me for thine enemy?
13:25 wilt thou break a leaf driven to and fro? and wilt thou pursue
th dri stubble?  13:26 for thou writest bitter thing against me, and
makest me to possess the iniqu of my youth.

13:27 thou puttest my feet also in the stocks, and lookest narrowly
unto all my paths; thou settest a print upon the heel of my feet.

13:28 and he, as a rotten thing, consumeth, as a garment that is moth
eaten.

14:1 man that is born of a woman is of few day and full of trouble.

14:2 He cometh forth like a flower, and is cut down: he fleeth also as
a shadow, and continueth not.

14:3 and doth thou open thine eye upon such an one, and bringest me
into judgment with thee?  14:4 who can bring a clean thing out of an
unclean? not one.

14:5 see hi day are determined, the number of hi month are with
thee, thou hast appoint hi bound that he cannot pass; 14:6 turn
from him, that he may rest, till he shall accomplish, as an hireling,
hi day.

14:7 for there is hope of a tree, if it be cut down, that it will
sprout again, and that the tender branch thereof will not cease.

14:8 though the root thereof wax old in the earth, and the stock
thereof die in the ground; 14:9 yet through the scent of water it will
bud, and bring forth bough like a plant.

14:10 but man dieth, and wasteth away: yea, man giveth up the ghost,
and where is he?  14:11 As the water fail from the sea, and the flood
decayeth and drieth up: 14:12 So man lieth down, and riseth not: till
th heaven be no more, they shall not awake, nor be rais out of
their sleep.

14:13 O that thou wouldest hide me in the grave, that thou wouldest
keep me secret, until thi wrath be past, that thou wouldest appoint me
a set time, and rememb me!  14:14 If a man die, shall he live again?
al the day of my appoint time will I wait, till my chang come.

14:15 thou shalt call, and I will answer thee: thou wilt have a desire
to the work of thine hands.

14:16 for now thou numberest my steps: dost thou not watch over my
sin?  14:17 My transgress is seal up in a bag, and thou sewest up
min iniquity.

14:18 and sure the mountain fall cometh to nought, and the rock
i remov out of hi place.

14:19 the water wear the stones: thou washest away the thing which
grow out of the dust of the earth; and thou destroyest the hope of
man.

14:20 thou prevailest for ever against him, and he passeth: thou
changest hi countenance, and sendest him away.

14:21 hi son come to honour, and he knoweth it not; and they are
brought low, but he perceiveth it not of them.

14:22 but hi flesh upon him shall have pain, and hi soul within him
shal mourn.

15:1 then answer eliphaz the temanite, and said, 15:2 should a wise
man utter vain knowledge, and fill hi belli with the east wind?  15:3
should he reason with unprofit talk? or with speech wherewith he
can do no good?  15:4 yea, thou castest off fear, and restrainest
pray befor god.

15:5 for thi mouth uttereth thine iniquity, and thou choosest the
tongu of the crafty.

15:6 thine own mouth condemneth thee, and not I: yea, thine own lips
testifi against thee.

15:7 art thou the first man that wa born? or wast thou made before
th hills?  15:8 hast thou heard the secret of god? and dost thou
restrain wisdom to thyself?  15:9 what knowest thou, that we know not?
what understandest thou, which is not in us?  15:10 with us are both
th grayhead and veri age men, much elder than thi father.

15:11 are the consol of god small with thee? is there ani secret
th with thee?  15:12 whi doth thine heart carri thee away? and what
do thi eye wink at, 15:13 that thou turnest thi spirit against god,
and lettest such word go out of thi mouth?  15:14 what is man, that
h should be clean? and he which is born of a woman, that he should be
righteous?  15:15 behold, he putteth no trust in hi saints; yea, the
heaven are not clean in hi sight.

15:16 how much more abomin and filthi is man, which drinketh
iniqu like water?  15:17 I will shew thee, hear me; and that which
i have seen I will declare; 15:18 which wise men have told from their
fathers, and have not hid it: 15:19 unto whom alon the earth was
given, and no stranger pass among them.

15:20 the wick man travaileth with pain all hi days, and the number
of year is hidden to the oppressor.

15:21 A dread sound is in hi ears: in prosper the destroyer
shal come upon him.

15:22 He believeth not that he shall return out of darkness, and he is
wait for of the sword.

15:23 He wandereth abroad for bread, saying, where is it? he knoweth
that the day of dark is readi at hi hand.

15:24 troubl and anguish shall make him afraid; they shall prevail
against him, as a king readi to the battle.

15:25 for he stretcheth out hi hand against god, and strengtheneth
himself against the almighty.

15:26 He runneth upon him, even on hi neck, upon the thick boss of
hi bucklers: 15:27 becaus he covereth hi face with hi fatness, and
maketh collop of fat on hi flanks.

15:28 and he dwelleth in desol cities, and in hous which no man
inhabiteth, which are readi to becom heaps.

15:29 He shall not be rich, neither shall hi substanc continue,
neith shall he prolong the perfect thereof upon the earth.

15:30 He shall not depart out of darkness; the flame shall dri up his
branches, and by the breath of hi mouth shall he go away.

15:31 let not him that is deceiv trust in vanity: for vaniti shall
b hi recompence.

15:32 It shall be accomplish befor hi time, and hi branch shall
not be green.

15:33 He shall shake off hi unrip grape as the vine, and shall cast
off hi flower as the olive.

15:34 for the congreg of hypocrit shall be desolate, and fire
shal consum the tabernacl of bribery.

15:35 they conceiv mischief, and bring forth vanity, and their belly
prepareth deceit.

16:1 then job answer and said, 16:2 I have heard mani such things:
miser comfort are ye all.

16:3 shall vain word have an end? or what emboldeneth thee that thou
answerest?  16:4 I also could speak as ye do: if your soul were in my
soul' stead, I could heap up word against you, and shake mine head
at you.

16:5 but I would strengthen you with my mouth, and the move of my
lip should asswag your grief.

16:6 though I speak, my grief is not asswaged: and though I forbear,
what am I eased?  16:7 but now he hath made me weary: thou hast made
desol all my company.

16:8 and thou hast fill me with wrinkles, which is a wit against
me: and my lean rise up in me beareth wit to my face.

16:9 He teareth me in hi wrath, who hateth me: he gnasheth upon me
with hi teeth; mine enemi sharpeneth hi eye upon me.

16:10 they have gape upon me with their mouth; they have smitten me
upon the cheek reproachfully; they have gather themselv together
against me.

16:11 god hath deliv me to the ungodly, and turn me over into
th hand of the wicked.

16:12 I wa at ease, but he hath broken me asunder: he hath also taken
m by my neck, and shaken me to pieces, and set me up for hi mark.

16:13 hi archer compass me round about, he cleaveth my reins
asunder, and doth not spare; he poureth out my gall upon the ground.

16:14 He breaketh me with breach upon breach, he runneth upon me like
a giant.

16:15 I have sew sackcloth upon my skin, and defil my horn in the
dust.

16:16 My face is foul with weeping, and on my eyelid is the shadow of
death; 16:17 not for ani injustic in mine hands: also my prayer is
pure.

16:18 O earth, cover not thou my blood, and let my cri have no place.

16:19 also now, behold, my wit is in heaven, and my record is on
high.

16:20 My friend scorn me: but mine eye poureth out tear unto god.

16:21 O that one might plead for a man with god, as a man pleadeth for
hi neighbour!  16:22 when a few year are come, then I shall go the
way whenc I shall not return.

17:1 My breath is corrupt, my day are extinct, the grave are ready
for me.

17:2 are there not mocker with me? and doth not mine eye continu in
their provocation?  17:3 lay down now, put me in a sureti with thee;
who is he that will strike hand with me?  17:4 for thou hast hid
their heart from understanding: therefor shalt thou not exalt them.

17:5 He that speaketh flatteri to hi friends, even the eye of his
children shall fail.

17:6 He hath made me also a byword of the people; and aforetim I was
a a tabret.

17:7 mine eye also is dim by reason of sorrow, and all my member are
a a shadow.

17:8 upright men shall be astoni at this, and the innoc shall
stir up himself against the hypocrite.

17:9 the righteou also shall hold on hi way, and he that hath clean
hand shall be stronger and stronger.

17:10 but as for you all, do ye return, and come now: for I cannot
find one wise man among you.

17:11 My day are past, my purpos are broken off, even the thoughts
of my heart.

17:12 they chang the night into day: the light is short becaus of
darkness.

17:13 If I wait, the grave is mine house: I have made my bed in the
darkness.

17:14 I have said to corruption, thou art my father: to the worm, thou
art my mother, and my sister.

17:15 and where is now my hope? as for my hope, who shall see it?
17:16 they shall go down to the bar of the pit, when our rest
togeth is in the dust.

18:1 then answer bildad the shuhite, and said, 18:2 how long will it
b ere ye make an end of words? mark, and afterward we will speak.

18:3 wherefor are we count as beasts, and reput vile in your
sight?  18:4 He teareth himself in hi anger: shall the earth be
forsaken for thee? and shall the rock be remov out of hi place?
18:5 yea, the light of the wick shall be put out, and the spark of
hi fire shall not shine.

18:6 the light shall be dark in hi tabernacle, and hi candl shall
b put out with him.

18:7 the step of hi strength shall be straitened, and hi own
counsel shall cast him down.

18:8 for he is cast into a net by hi own feet, and he walketh upon a
snare.

18:9 the gin shall take him by the heel, and the robber shall prevail
against him.

18:10 the snare is laid for him in the ground, and a trap for him in
th way.

18:11 terror shall make him afraid on everi side, and shall drive him
to hi feet.

18:12 hi strength shall be hungerbitten, and destruct shall be
readi at hi side.

18:13 It shall devour the strength of hi skin: even the firstborn of
death shall devour hi strength.

18:14 hi confid shall be root out of hi tabernacle, and it
shal bring him to the king of terrors.

18:15 It shall dwell in hi tabernacle, becaus it is none of his:
brimston shall be scatter upon hi habitation.

18:16 hi root shall be dri up beneath, and abov shall hi branch
b cut off.

18:17 hi remembr shall perish from the earth, and he shall have
no name in the street.

18:18 He shall be driven from light into darkness, and chase out of
th world.

18:19 He shall neither have son nor nephew among hi people, nor any
remain in hi dwellings.

18:20 they that come after him shall be astoni at hi day, as they
that went befor were affrighted.

18:21 sure such are the dwell of the wicked, and thi is the
plac of him that knoweth not god.

19:1 then job answer and said, 19:2 how long will ye vex my soul,
and break me in piec with words?  19:3 these ten time have ye
reproach me: ye are not asham that ye make yourselv strang to
me.

19:4 and be it inde that I have erred, mine error remaineth with
myself.

19:5 If inde ye will magnifi yourselv against me, and plead
against me my reproach: 19:6 know now that god hath overthrown me, and
hath compass me with hi net.

19:7 behold, I cri out of wrong, but I am not heard: I cri aloud, but
ther is no judgment.

19:8 He hath fenc up my way that I cannot pass, and he hath set
dark in my paths.

19:9 He hath strip me of my glory, and taken the crown from my
head.

19:10 He hath destroy me on everi side, and I am gone: and mine hope
hath he remov like a tree.

19:11 He hath also kindl hi wrath against me, and he counteth me
unto him as one of hi enemies.

19:12 hi troop come together, and rais up their way against me, and
encamp round about my tabernacle.

19:13 He hath put my brethren far from me, and mine acquaint are
verili estrang from me.

19:14 My kinsfolk have failed, and my familiar friend have forgotten
me.

19:15 they that dwell in mine house, and my maids, count me for a
stranger: I am an alien in their sight.

19:16 I call my servant, and he gave me no answer; I intreat him
with my mouth.

19:17 My breath is strang to my wife, though I intreat for the
children' sake of mine own body.

19:18 yea, young children despis me; I arose, and they spake against
me.

19:19 all my inward friend abhor me: and they whom I love are
turn against me.

19:20 My bone cleaveth to my skin and to my flesh, and I am escaped
with the skin of my teeth.

19:21 have piti upon me, have piti upon me, O ye my friends; for the
hand of god hath touch me.

19:22 whi do ye persecut me as god, and are not satisfi with my
flesh?  19:23 Oh that my word were now written! oh that they were
print in a book!  19:24 that they were graven with an iron pen and
lead in the rock for ever!  19:25 for I know that my redeem liveth,
and that he shall stand at the latter day upon the earth: 19:26 and
though after my skin worm destroy thi body, yet in my flesh shall i
se god: 19:27 whom I shall see for myself, and mine eye shall
behold, and not another; though my rein be consum within me.

19:28 but ye should say, whi persecut we him, see the root of the
matt is found in me?  19:29 Be ye afraid of the sword: for wrath
bringeth the punish of the sword, that ye may know there is a
judgment.

20:1 then answer zophar the naamathite, and said, 20:2 therefor do
mi thought caus me to answer, and for thi I make haste.

20:3 I have heard the check of my reproach, and the spirit of my
understand causeth me to answer.

20:4 knowest thou not thi of old, sinc man wa place upon earth,
20:5 that the triumph of the wick is short, and the joy of the
hypocrit but for a moment?  20:6 though hi excel mount up to
th heavens, and hi head reach unto the clouds; 20:7 yet he shall
perish for ever like hi own dung: they which have seen him shall say,
wher is he?  20:8 He shall fli away as a dream, and shall not be
found: yea, he shall be chase away as a vision of the night.

20:9 the eye also which saw him shall see him no more; neither shall
hi place ani more behold him.

20:10 hi children shall seek to pleas the poor, and hi hand shall
restor their goods.

20:11 hi bone are full of the sin of hi youth, which shall lie down
with him in the dust.

20:12 though wicked be sweet in hi mouth, though he hide it under
hi tongue; 20:13 though he spare it, and forsak it not; but keep it
stil within hi mouth: 20:14 yet hi meat in hi bowel is turned, it
i the gall of asp within him.

20:15 He hath swallow down riches, and he shall vomit them up again:
god shall cast them out of hi belly.

20:16 He shall suck the poison of asps: the viper' tongu shall slay
him.

20:17 He shall not see the rivers, the floods, the brook of honey and
butter.

20:18 that which he labour for shall he restore, and shall not
swallow it down: accord to hi substanc shall the restitut be,
and he shall not rejoic therein.

20:19 becaus he hath oppress and hath forsaken the poor; becaus he
hath violent taken away an hous which he build not; 20:20 surely
h shall not feel quiet in hi belly, he shall not save of that
which he desired.

20:21 there shall none of hi meat be left; therefor shall no man
look for hi goods.

20:22 In the ful of hi suffici he shall be in straits: every
hand of the wick shall come upon him.

20:23 when he is about to fill hi belly, god shall cast the furi of
hi wrath upon him, and shall rain it upon him while he is eating.

20:24 He shall flee from the iron weapon, and the bow of steel shall
strik him through.

20:25 It is drawn, and cometh out of the body; yea, the glittering
sword cometh out of hi gall: terror are upon him.

20:26 all dark shall be hid in hi secret places: a fire not blown
shal consum him; it shall go ill with him that is left in his
tabernacle.

20:27 the heaven shall reveal hi iniquity; and the earth shall rise
up against him.

20:28 the increas of hi hous shall depart, and hi good shall flow
away in the day of hi wrath.

20:29 thi is the portion of a wick man from god, and the heritage
appoint unto him by god.

21:1 but job answer and said, 21:2 hear dilig my speech, and
let thi be your consolations.

21:3 suffer me that I may speak; and after that I have spoken, mock
on.

21:4 As for me, is my complaint to man? and if it were so, whi should
not my spirit be troubled?  21:5 mark me, and be astonished, and lay
your hand upon your mouth.

21:6 even when I rememb I am afraid, and trembl taketh hold on my
flesh.

21:7 wherefor do the wick live, becom old, yea, are mighti in
power?  21:8 their seed is establish in their sight with them, and
their offspr befor their eyes.

21:9 their hous are safe from fear, neither is the rod of god upon
them.

21:10 their bull gendereth, and faileth not; their cow calveth, and
casteth not her calf.

21:11 they send forth their littl one like a flock, and their
children dance.

21:12 they take the timbrel and harp, and rejoic at the sound of the
organ.

21:13 they spend their day in wealth, and in a moment go down to the
grave.

21:14 therefor they say unto god, depart from us; for we desir not
th knowledg of thi ways.

21:15 what is the almighty, that we should serv him? and what profit
should we have, if we pray unto him?  21:16 lo, their good is not in
their hand: the counsel of the wick is far from me.

21:17 how oft is the candl of the wick put out! and how oft cometh
their destruct upon them! god distributeth sorrow in hi anger.

21:18 they are as stubbl befor the wind, and as chaff that the storm
carrieth away.

21:19 god layeth up hi iniqu for hi children: he rewardeth him,
and he shall know it.

21:20 hi eye shall see hi destruction, and he shall drink of the
wrath of the almighty.

21:21 for what pleasur hath he in hi hous after him, when the
numb of hi month is cut off in the midst?  21:22 shall ani teach
god knowledge? see he judgeth those that are high.

21:23 one dieth in hi full strength, be wholli at eas and quiet.

21:24 hi breast are full of milk, and hi bone are moisten with
marrow.

21:25 and anoth dieth in the bitter of hi soul, and never
eateth with pleasure.

21:26 they shall lie down alik in the dust, and the worm shall cover
them.

21:27 behold, I know your thoughts, and the devic which ye
wrong imagin against me.

21:28 for ye say, where is the hous of the prince? and where are the
dwel place of the wicked?  21:29 have ye not ask them that go
bi the way? and do ye not know their tokens, 21:30 that the wick is
reserv to the day of destruction? they shall be brought forth to the
day of wrath.

21:31 who shall declar hi way to hi face? and who shall repay him
what he hath done?  21:32 yet shall he be brought to the grave, and
shal remain in the tomb.

21:33 the clod of the valley shall be sweet unto him, and everi man
shal draw after him, as there are innumer befor him.

21:34 how then comfort ye me in vain, see in your answer there
remaineth falsehood?  22:1 then eliphaz the temanit answer and
said, 22:2 can a man be profit unto god, as he that is wise may be
profit unto himself?  22:3 Is it ani pleasur to the almighty,
that thou art righteous? or is it gain to him, that thou makest thy
way perfect?  22:4 will he reprov thee for fear of thee? will he
ent with thee into judgment?  22:5 Is not thi wicked great? and
thin iniqu infinite?  22:6 for thou hast taken a pledg from thy
broth for nought, and strip the nake of their clothing.

22:7 thou hast not given water to the weari to drink, and thou hast
withholden bread from the hungry.

22:8 but as for the mighti man, he had the earth; and the honourable
man dwelt in it.

22:9 thou hast sent widow away empty, and the arm of the fatherless
hav been broken.

22:10 therefor snare are round about thee, and sudden fear troubleth
thee; 22:11 Or darkness, that thou canst not see; and abund of
wat cover thee.

22:12 Is not god in the height of heaven? and behold the height of the
stars, how high they are!  22:13 and thou sayest, how doth god know?
can he judg through the dark cloud?  22:14 thick cloud are a
cov to him, that he seeth not; and he walketh in the circuit of
heaven.

22:15 hast thou mark the old way which wick men have trodden?
22:16 which were cut down out of time, whose foundat wa overflown
with a flood: 22:17 which said unto god, depart from us: and what can
th almighti do for them?  22:18 yet he fill their hous with good
things: but the counsel of the wick is far from me.

22:19 the righteou see it, and are glad: and the innoc laugh them
to scorn.

22:20 wherea our substanc is not cut down, but the remnant of them
th fire consumeth.

22:21 acquaint now thyself with him, and be at peace: therebi good
shal come unto thee.

22:22 receive, I pray thee, the law from hi mouth, and lay up his
word in thine heart.

22:23 If thou return to the almighty, thou shalt be built up, thou
shalt put away iniqu far from thi tabernacles.

22:24 then shalt thou lay up gold as dust, and the gold of ophir as
th stone of the brooks.

22:25 yea, the almighti shall be thi defence, and thou shalt have
plenti of silver.

22:26 for then shalt thou have thi delight in the almighty, and shalt
lift up thi face unto god.

22:27 thou shalt make thi prayer unto him, and he shall hear thee, and
thou shalt pay thi vows.

22:28 thou shalt also decre a thing, and it shall be establish unto
thee: and the light shall shine upon thi ways.

22:29 when men are cast down, then thou shalt say, there is lifting
up; and he shall save the humbl person.

22:30 He shall deliv the island of the innocent: and it is delivered
bi the pure of thine hands.

23:1 then job answer and said, 23:2 even to day is my complaint
bitter: my stroke is heavier than my groaning.

23:3 Oh that I knew where I might find him! that I might come even to
hi seat!  23:4 I would order my caus befor him, and fill my mouth
with arguments.

23:5 I would know the word which he would answer me, and understand
what he would say unto me.

23:6 will he plead against me with hi great power? no; but he would
put strength in me.

23:7 there the righteou might disput with him; so should I be
deliv for ever from my judge.

23:8 behold, I go forward, but he is not there; and backward, but i
cannot perceiv him: 23:9 On the left hand, where he doth work, but i
cannot behold him: he hideth himself on the right hand, that I cannot
se him: 23:10 but he knoweth the way that I take: when he hath tried
me, I shall come forth as gold.

23:11 My foot hath held hi steps, hi way have I kept, and not
declined.

23:12 neither have I gone back from the command of hi lips; i
hav esteem the word of hi mouth more than my necessari food.

23:13 but he is in one mind, and who can turn him? and what hi soul
desireth, even that he doeth.

23:14 for he performeth the thing that is appoint for me: and many
such thing are with him.

23:15 therefor am I troubl at hi presence: when I consider, I am
afraid of him.

23:16 for god maketh my heart soft, and the almighti troubleth me:
23:17 becaus I wa not cut off befor the darkness, neither hath he
cov the dark from my face.

24:1 why, see time are not hidden from the almighty, do they that
know him not see hi days?  24:2 some remov the landmarks; they
viol take away flocks, and feed thereof.

24:3 they drive away the ass of the fatherless, they take the widow's
ox for a pledge.

24:4 they turn the needi out of the way: the poor of the earth hide
themselv together.

24:5 behold, as wild ass in the desert, go they forth to their work;
ris betim for a prey: the wilder yieldeth food for them and
for their children.

24:6 they reap everi one hi corn in the field: and they gather the
vintag of the wicked.

24:7 they caus the nake to lodg without clothing, that they have no
cov in the cold.

24:8 they are wet with the shower of the mountains, and embrac the
rock for want of a shelter.

24:9 they pluck the fatherless from the breast, and take a pledg of
th poor.

24:10 they caus him to go nake without clothing, and they take away
th sheaf from the hungry; 24:11 which make oil within their walls,
and tread their winepresses, and suffer thirst.

24:12 men groan from out of the city, and the soul of the wounded
crieth out: yet god layeth not folli to them.

24:13 they are of those that rebel against the light; they know not
th way thereof, nor abid in the path thereof.

24:14 the murder rise with the light killeth the poor and needy,
and in the night is as a thief.

24:15 the eye also of the adulter waiteth for the twilight, saying,
no eye shall see me: and disguiseth hi face.

24:16 In the dark they dig through houses, which they had mark for
themselv in the daytime: they know not the light.

24:17 for the morn is to them even as the shadow of death: if one
know them, they are in the terror of the shadow of death.

24:18 He is swift as the waters; their portion is curs in the earth:
h beholdeth not the way of the vineyards.

24:19 drought and heat consum the snow waters: so doth the grave
thos which have sinned.

24:20 the womb shall forget him; the worm shall feed sweetli on him;
h shall be no more remembered; and wicked shall be broken as a
tree.

24:21 He evil entreateth the barren that beareth not: and doeth not
good to the widow.

24:22 He draweth also the mighti with hi power: he riseth up, and no
man is sure of life.

24:23 though it be given him to be in safety, whereon he resteth; yet
hi eye are upon their ways.

24:24 they are exalt for a littl while, but are gone and brought
low; they are taken out of the way as all other, and cut off as the
top of the ear of corn.

24:25 and if it be not so now, who will make me a liar, and make my
speech noth worth?  25:1 then answer bildad the shuhite, and
said, 25:2 dominion and fear are with him, he maketh peac in hi high
places.

25:3 Is there ani number of hi armies? and upon whom doth not his
light arise?  25:4 how then can man be justifi with god? or how can
h be clean that is born of a woman?  25:5 behold even to the moon,
and it shineth not; yea, the star are not pure in hi sight.

25:6 how much less man, that is a worm? and the son of man, which is a
worm?  26:1 but job answer and said, 26:2 how hast thou help him
that is without power? how savest thou the arm that hath no strength?
26:3 how hast thou counsel him that hath no wisdom? and how hast
thou plenti declar the thing as it is?  26:4 To whom hast thou
utt words? and whose spirit came from thee?  26:5 dead thing are
form from under the waters, and the inhabit thereof.

26:6 hell is nake befor him, and destruct hath no covering.

26:7 He stretcheth out the north over the empti place, and hangeth the
earth upon nothing.

26:8 He bindeth up the water in hi thick clouds; and the cloud is
not rent under them.

26:9 He holdeth back the face of hi throne, and spreadeth hi cloud
upon it.

26:10 He hath compass the water with bounds, until the day and
night come to an end.

26:11 the pillar of heaven trembl and are astonish at hi reproof.

26:12 He divideth the sea with hi power, and by hi understand he
smiteth through the proud.

26:13 By hi spirit he hath garnish the heavens; hi hand hath
form the crook serpent.

26:14 lo, these are part of hi ways: but how littl a portion is
heard of him? but the thunder of hi power who can understand?  27:1
moreov job continu hi parable, and said, 27:2 As god liveth, who
hath taken away my judgment; and the almighty, who hath vex my soul;
27:3 all the while my breath is in me, and the spirit of god is in my
nostrils; 27:4 My lip shall not speak wickedness, nor my tongu utter
deceit.

27:5 god forbid that I should justifi you: till I die I will not
remov mine integr from me.

27:6 My righteous I hold fast, and will not let it go: my heart
shal not reproach me so long as I live.

27:7 let mine enemi be as the wicked, and he that riseth up against me
a the unrighteous.

27:8 for what is the hope of the hypocrite, though he hath gained,
when god taketh away hi soul?  27:9 will god hear hi cri when
troubl cometh upon him?  27:10 will he delight himself in the
almighty? will he alway call upon god?  27:11 I will teach you by the
hand of god: that which is with the almighti will I not conceal.

27:12 behold, all ye yourselv have seen it; whi then are ye thus
altogeth vain?  27:13 thi is the portion of a wick man with god,
and the heritag of oppressors, which they shall receiv of the
almighty.

27:14 If hi children be multiplied, it is for the sword: and his
offspr shall not be satisfi with bread.

27:15 those that remain of him shall be buri in death: and his
widow shall not weep.

27:16 though he heap up silver as the dust, and prepar raiment as the
clay; 27:17 He may prepar it, but the just shall put it on, and the
innoc shall divid the silver.

27:18 He buildeth hi hous as a moth, and as a booth that the keeper
maketh.

27:19 the rich man shall lie down, but he shall not be gathered: he
openeth hi eyes, and he is not.

27:20 terror take hold on him as waters, a tempest stealeth him away
in the night.

27:21 the east wind carrieth him away, and he departeth: and as a
storm hurleth him out of hi place.

27:22 for god shall cast upon him, and not spare: he would fain flee
out of hi hand.

27:23 men shall clap their hand at him, and shall hiss him out of his
place.

28:1 sure there is a vein for the silver, and a place for gold where
they fine it.

28:2 iron is taken out of the earth, and brass is molten out of the
stone.

28:3 He setteth an end to darkness, and searcheth out all perfection:
th stone of darkness, and the shadow of death.

28:4 the flood breaketh out from the inhabitant; even the waters
forgotten of the foot: they are dri up, they are gone away from men.

28:5 As for the earth, out of it cometh bread: and under it is turned
up as it were fire.

28:6 the stone of it are the place of sapphires: and it hath dust of
gold.

28:7 there is a path which no fowl knoweth, and which the vulture's
ey hath not seen: 28:8 the lion' whelp have not trodden it, nor the
fierc lion pass by it.

28:9 He putteth forth hi hand upon the rock; he overturneth the
mountain by the roots.

28:10 He cutteth out river among the rocks; and hi eye seeth every
preci thing.

28:11 He bindeth the flood from overflowing; and the thing that is
hid bringeth he forth to light.

28:12 but where shall wisdom be found? and where is the place of
understanding?  28:13 man knoweth not the price thereof; neither is it
found in the land of the living.

28:14 the depth saith, It is not in me: and the sea saith, It is not
with me.

28:15 It cannot be gotten for gold, neither shall silver be weighed
for the price thereof.

28:16 It cannot be valu with the gold of ophir, with the precious
onyx, or the sapphire.

28:17 the gold and the crystal cannot equal it: and the exchang of it
shal not be for jewel of fine gold.

28:18 No mention shall be made of coral, or of pearls: for the price
of wisdom is abov rubies.

28:19 the topaz of ethiopia shall not equal it, neither shall it be
valu with pure gold.

28:20 whenc then cometh wisdom? and where is the place of
understanding?  28:21 see it is hid from the eye of all living,
and kept close from the fowl of the air.

28:22 destruct and death say, We have heard the fame thereof with
our ears.

28:23 god understandeth the way thereof, and he knoweth the place
thereof.

28:24 for he looketh to the end of the earth, and seeth under the
whol heaven; 28:25 To make the weight for the winds; and he weigheth
th water by measure.

28:26 when he made a decre for the rain, and a way for the lightning
of the thunder: 28:27 then did he see it, and declar it; he prepared
it, yea, and search it out.

28:28 and unto man he said, behold, the fear of the lord, that is
wisdom; and to depart from evil is understanding.

29:1 moreov job continu hi parable, and said, 29:2 Oh that I were
a in month past, as in the day when god preserv me; 29:3 when his
candl shine upon my head, and when by hi light I walk through
darkness; 29:4 As I wa in the day of my youth, when the secret of
god wa upon my tabernacle; 29:5 when the almighti wa yet with me,
when my children were about me; 29:6 when I wash my step with
butter, and the rock pour me out river of oil; 29:7 when I went out
to the gate through the city, when I prepar my seat in the street!
29:8 the young men saw me, and hid themselves: and the age arose, and
stood up.

29:9 the princ refrain talking, and laid their hand on their
mouth.

29:10 the nobl held their peace, and their tongu cleav to the
roof of their mouth.

29:11 when the ear heard me, then it bless me; and when the eye saw
me, it gave wit to me: 29:12 becaus I deliv the poor that
cried, and the fatherless, and him that had none to help him.

29:13 the bless of him that wa readi to perish came upon me: and i
caus the widow' heart to sing for joy.

29:14 I put on righteousness, and it cloth me: my judgment wa as a
rob and a diadem.

29:15 I wa eye to the blind, and feet wa I to the lame.

29:16 I wa a father to the poor: and the caus which I knew not i
search out.

29:17 and I brake the jaw of the wicked, and pluck the spoil out of
hi teeth.

29:18 then I said, I shall die in my nest, and I shall multipli my
day as the sand.

29:19 My root wa spread out by the waters, and the dew lay all night
upon my branch.

29:20 My glori wa fresh in me, and my bow wa renew in my hand.

29:21 unto me men gave ear, and waited, and kept silenc at my
counsel.

29:22 after my word they spake not again; and my speech drop upon
them.

29:23 and they wait for me as for the rain; and they open their
mouth wide as for the latter rain.

29:24 If I laugh on them, they believ it not; and the light of my
counten they cast not down.

29:25 I chose out their way, and sat chief, and dwelt as a king in the
army, as one that comforteth the mourners.

30:1 but now they that are younger than I have me in derision, whose
fath I would have disdain to have set with the dog of my flock.

30:2 yea, whereto might the strength of their hand profit me, in whom
old age wa perished?  30:3 for want and famin they were solitary;
fle into the wilder in former time desol and waste.

30:4 who cut up mallow by the bushes, and junip root for their
meat.

30:5 they were driven forth from among men, (they cri after them as
aft a thief;) 30:6 To dwell in the cliff of the valleys, in caves
of the earth, and in the rocks.

30:7 among the bush they brayed; under the nettl they were
gath together.

30:8 they were children of fools, yea, children of base men: they were
vil than the earth.

30:9 and now am I their song, yea, I am their byword.

30:10 they abhor me, they flee far from me, and spare not to spit in
mi face.

30:11 becaus he hath loos my cord, and afflict me, they have also
let loos the bridl befor me.

30:12 upon my right hand rise the youth; they push away my feet, and
they rais up against me the way of their destruction.

30:13 they mar my path, they set forward my calamity, they have no
helper.

30:14 they came upon me as a wide break in of waters: in the
desol they roll themselv upon me.

30:15 terror are turn upon me: they pursu my soul as the wind: and
mi welfar passeth away as a cloud.

30:16 and now my soul is pour out upon me; the day of affliction
hav taken hold upon me.

30:17 My bone are pierc in me in the night season: and my sinews
tak no rest.

30:18 By the great forc of my diseas is my garment changed: it
bindeth me about as the collar of my coat.

30:19 He hath cast me into the mire, and I am becom like dust and
ashes.

30:20 I cri unto thee, and thou dost not hear me: I stand up, and thou
regardest me not.

30:21 thou art becom cruel to me: with thi strong hand thou opposest
thyself against me.

30:22 thou liftest me up to the wind; thou causest me to ride upon it,
and dissolvest my substance.

30:23 for I know that thou wilt bring me to death, and to the house
appoint for all living.

30:24 howbeit he will not stretch out hi hand to the grave, though
they cri in hi destruction.

30:25 did not I weep for him that wa in trouble? wa not my soul
griev for the poor?  30:26 when I look for good, then evil came
unto me: and when I wait for light, there came darkness.

30:27 My bowel boiled, and rest not: the day of affliction
prev me.

30:28 I went mourn without the sun: I stood up, and I cri in the
congregation.

30:29 I am a brother to dragons, and a companion to owls.

30:30 My skin is black upon me, and my bone are burn with heat.

30:31 My harp also is turn to mourning, and my organ into the voice
of them that weep.

31:1 I made a coven with mine eyes; whi then should I think upon a
maid?  31:2 for what portion of god is there from above? and what
inherit of the almighti from on high?  31:3 Is not destruct to
th wicked? and a strang punish to the worker of iniquity?  31:4
doth not he see my ways, and count all my steps?  31:5 If I have
walk with vanity, or if my foot hath hast to deceit; 31:6 let me
b weigh in an even balanc that god may know mine integrity.

31:7 If my step hath turn out of the way, and mine heart walked
aft mine eyes, and if ani blot hath cleav to mine hands; 31:8 then
let me sow, and let anoth eat; yea, let my offspr be root out.

31:9 If mine heart have been deceiv by a woman, or if I have laid
wait at my neighbour' door; 31:10 then let my wife grind unto
another, and let other bow down upon her.

31:11 for thi is an heinou crime; yea, it is an iniqu to be
punish by the judges.

31:12 for it is a fire that consumeth to destruction, and would root
out all mine increase.

31:13 If I did despis the caus of my manserv or of my
maidservant, when they contend with me; 31:14 what then shall I do
when god riseth up? and when he visiteth, what shall I answer him?
31:15 did not he that made me in the womb make him? and did not one
fashion us in the womb?  31:16 If I have withheld the poor from their
desire, or have caus the eye of the widow to fail; 31:17 Or have
eaten my morsel myself alone, and the fatherless hath not eaten
thereof; 31:18 (for from my youth he wa brought up with me, as with a
father, and I have guid her from my mother' womb;) 31:19 If I have
seen ani perish for want of clothing, or ani poor without covering;
31:20 If hi loin have not bless me, and if he were not warm with
th fleec of my sheep; 31:21 If I have lift up my hand against the
fatherless, when I saw my help in the gate: 31:22 then let mine arm
fal from my shoulder blade, and mine arm be broken from the bone.

31:23 for destruct from god wa a terror to me, and by reason of
hi high I could not endure.

31:24 If I have made gold my hope, or have said to the fine gold, thou
art my confidence; 31:25 If I rejoic becaus my wealth wa great, and
becaus mine hand had gotten much; 31:26 If I beheld the sun when it
shined, or the moon walk in brightness; 31:27 and my heart hath
been secretli enticed, or my mouth hath kiss my hand: 31:28 this
also were an iniqu to be punish by the judge: for I should have
deni the god that is above.

31:29 If I rejoic at the destruct of him that hate me, or lifted
up myself when evil found him: 31:30 neither have I suffer my mouth
to sin by wish a curs to hi soul.

31:31 If the men of my tabernacl said not, Oh that we had of his
flesh!  we cannot be satisfied.

31:32 the stranger did not lodg in the street: but I open my doors
to the traveller.

31:33 If I cover my transgress as adam, by hide mine iniquity
in my bosom: 31:34 did I fear a great multitude, or did the contempt
of famili terrifi me, that I kept silence, and went not out of the
door?  31:35 Oh that one would hear me! behold, my desir is, that the
almighti would answer me, and that mine adversari had written a book.

31:36 sure I would take it upon my shoulder, and bind it as a crown
to me.

31:37 I would declar unto him the number of my steps; as a prince
would I go near unto him.

31:38 If my land cri against me, or that the furrow likewis thereof
complain; 31:39 If I have eaten the fruit thereof without money, or
hav caus the owner thereof to lose their life: 31:40 let thistles
grow instead of wheat, and cockl instead of barley.

th word of job are ended.

32:1 So these three men ceas to answer job, becaus he wa righteous
in hi own eyes.

32:2 then wa kindl the wrath of elihu the son of barachel the
buzite, of the kindr of ram: against job wa hi wrath kindled,
becaus he justifi himself rather than god.

32:3 also against hi three friend wa hi wrath kindled, because
they had found no answer, and yet had condemn job.

32:4 now elihu had wait till job had spoken, becaus they were elder
than he.

32:5 when elihu saw that there wa no answer in the mouth of these
thre men, then hi wrath wa kindled.

32:6 and elihu the son of barachel the buzit answer and said, I am
young, and ye are veri old; wherefor I wa afraid, and durst not shew
you mine opinion.

32:7 I said, day should speak, and multitud of year should teach
wisdom.

32:8 but there is a spirit in man: and the inspir of the almighty
giveth them understanding.

32:9 great men are not alway wise: neither do the age understand
judgment.

32:10 therefor I said, hearken to me; I also will shew mine opinion.

32:11 behold, I wait for your words; I gave ear to your reasons,
whilst ye search out what to say.

32:12 yea, I attend unto you, and, behold, there wa none of you
that convinc job, or that answer hi words: 32:13 lest ye should
say, We have found out wisdom: god thrusteth him down, not man.

32:14 now he hath not direct hi word against me: neither will i
answ him with your speeches.

32:15 they were amazed, they answer no more: they left off speaking.

32:16 when I had waited, (for they spake not, but stood still, and
answ no more;) 32:17 I said, I will answer also my part, I also
wil shew mine opinion.

32:18 for I am full of matter, the spirit within me constraineth me.

32:19 behold, my belli is as wine which hath no vent; it is readi to
burst like new bottles.

32:20 I will speak, that I may be refreshed: I will open my lip and
answer.

32:21 let me not, I pray you, accept ani man' person, neither let me
giv flatter titl unto man.

32:22 for I know not to give flatter titles; in so do my maker
would soon take me away.

33:1 wherefore, job, I pray thee, hear my speeches, and hearken to all
mi words.

33:2 behold, now I have open my mouth, my tongu hath spoken in my
mouth.

33:3 My word shall be of the upright of my heart: and my lips
shal utter knowledg clearly.

33:4 the spirit of god hath made me, and the breath of the almighty
hath given me life.

33:5 If thou canst answer me, set thi word in order befor me, stand
up.

33:6 behold, I am accord to thi wish in god' stead: I also am
form out of the clay.

33:7 behold, my terror shall not make thee afraid, neither shall my
hand be heavi upon thee.

33:8 sure thou hast spoken in mine hearing, and I have heard the
voic of thi words, saying, 33:9 I am clean without transgression, i
am innocent; neither is there iniqu in me.

33:10 behold, he findeth occas against me, he counteth me for his
enemy, 33:11 He putteth my feet in the stocks, he marketh all my
paths.

33:12 behold, in thi thou art not just: I will answer thee, that god
i greater than man.

33:13 whi dost thou strive against him? for he giveth not account of
ani of hi matters.

33:14 for god speaketh once, yea twice, yet man perceiveth it not.

33:15 In a dream, in a vision of the night, when deep sleep falleth
upon men, in slumber upon the bed; 33:16 then he openeth the ears
of men, and sealeth their instruction, 33:17 that he may withdraw man
from hi purpose, and hide pride from man.

33:18 He keepeth back hi soul from the pit, and hi life from
perish by the sword.

33:19 He is chasten also with pain upon hi bed, and the multitude
of hi bone with strong pain: 33:20 So that hi life abhorreth bread,
and hi soul dainti meat.

33:21 hi flesh is consum away, that it cannot be seen; and his
bon that were not seen stick out.

33:22 yea, hi soul draweth near unto the grave, and hi life to the
destroyers.

33:23 If there be a messeng with him, an interpreter, one among a
thousand, to shew unto man hi uprightness: 33:24 then he is gracious
unto him, and saith, deliv him from go down to the pit: I have
found a ransom.

33:25 hi flesh shall be fresher than a child's: he shall return to
th day of hi youth: 33:26 He shall pray unto god, and he will be
favour unto him: and he shall see hi face with joy: for he will
rend unto man hi righteousness.

33:27 He looketh upon men, and if ani say, I have sinned, and
pervert that which wa right, and it profit me not; 33:28 He will
deliv hi soul from go into the pit, and hi life shall see the
light.

33:29 lo, all these thing worketh god oftentim with man, 33:30 to
br back hi soul from the pit, to be enlighten with the light of
th living.

33:31 mark well, O job, hearken unto me: hold thi peace, and I will
speak.

33:32 If thou hast anyth to say, answer me: speak, for I desir to
justifi thee.

33:33 If not, hearken unto me: hold thi peace, and I shall teach thee
wisdom.

34:1 furthermor elihu answer and said, 34:2 hear my words, O ye
wis men; and give ear unto me, ye that have knowledge.

34:3 for the ear trieth words, as the mouth tasteth meat.

34:4 let us choos to us judgment: let us know among ourselv what is
good.

34:5 for job hath said, I am righteous: and god hath taken away my
judgment.

34:6 should I lie against my right? my wound is incur without
transgression.

34:7 what man is like job, who drinketh up scorn like water?  34:8
which goeth in compani with the worker of iniquity, and walketh with
wick men.

34:9 for he hath said, It profiteth a man noth that he should
delight himself with god.

34:10 therefor hearken unto me ye men of understanding: far be it
from god, that he should do wickedness; and from the almighty, that he
should commit iniquity.

34:11 for the work of a man shall he render unto him, and caus every
man to find accord to hi ways.

34:12 yea, sure god will not do wickedly, neither will the almighty
pervert judgment.

34:13 who hath given him a charg over the earth? or who hath disposed
th whole world?  34:14 If he set hi heart upon man, if he gather
unto himself hi spirit and hi breath; 34:15 all flesh shall perish
together, and man shall turn again unto dust.

34:16 If now thou hast understanding, hear this: hearken to the voice
of my words.

34:17 shall even he that hateth right govern? and wilt thou condemn
him that is most just?  34:18 Is it fit to say to a king, thou art
wicked? and to princes, Ye are ungodly?  34:19 how much less to him
that accepteth not the person of princes, nor regardeth the rich more
than the poor? for they all are the work of hi hands.

34:20 In a moment shall they die, and the peopl shall be troubl at
midnight, and pass away: and the mighti shall be taken away without
hand.

34:21 for hi eye are upon the way of man, and he seeth all his
goings.

34:22 there is no darkness, nor shadow of death, where the worker of
iniqu may hide themselves.

34:23 for he will not lay upon man more than right; that he should
ent into judgment with god.

34:24 He shall break in piec mighti men without number, and set
oth in their stead.

34:25 therefor he knoweth their works, and he overturneth them in the
night, so that they are destroyed.

34:26 He striketh them as wick men in the open sight of others;
34:27 becaus they turn back from him, and would not consid ani of
hi ways: 34:28 So that they caus the cri of the poor to come unto
him, and he heareth the cri of the afflicted.

34:29 when he giveth quietness, who then can make trouble? and when he
hideth hi face, who then can behold him? whether it be done against a
nation, or against a man only: 34:30 that the hypocrit reign not,
lest the peopl be ensnared.

34:31 sure it is meet to be said unto god, I have borne
chastisement, I will not offend ani more: 34:32 that which I see not
teach thou me: if I have done iniquity, I will do no more.

34:33 should it be accord to thi mind? he will recompens it,
wheth thou refuse, or whether thou choose; and not I: therefore
speak what thou knowest.

34:34 let men of understand tell me, and let a wise man hearken
unto me.

34:35 job hath spoken without knowledge, and hi word were without
wisdom.

34:36 My desir is that job may be tri unto the end becaus of his
answ for wick men.

34:37 for he addeth rebellion unto hi sin, he clappeth hi hands
among us, and multiplieth hi word against god.

35:1 elihu spake moreover, and said, 35:2 thinkest thou thi to be
right, that thou saidst, My righteous is more than god's?  35:3
for thou saidst, what advantag will it be unto thee? and, what profit
shal I have, if I be cleans from my sin?  35:4 I will answer thee,
and thi companion with thee.

35:5 look unto the heavens, and see; and behold the cloud which are
high than thou.

35:6 If thou sinnest, what doest thou against him? or if thy
transgress be multiplied, what doest thou unto him?  35:7 If thou
b righteous, what givest thou him? or what receiveth he of thine
hand?  35:8 thi wicked may hurt a man as thou art; and thy
right may profit the son of man.

35:9 By reason of the multitud of oppress they make the oppressed
to cry: they cri out by reason of the arm of the mighty.

35:10 but none saith, where is god my maker, who giveth song in the
night; 35:11 who teacheth us more than the beast of the earth, and
maketh us wiser than the fowl of heaven?  35:12 there they cry, but
non giveth answer, becaus of the pride of evil men.

35:13 sure god will not hear vanity, neither will the almighty
regard it.

35:14 although thou sayest thou shalt not see him, yet judgment is
befor him; therefor trust thou in him.

35:15 but now, becaus it is not so, he hath visit in hi anger; yet
h knoweth it not in great extremity: 35:16 therefor doth job open
hi mouth in vain; he multiplieth word without knowledge.

36:1 elihu also proceeded, and said, 36:2 suffer me a little, and i
wil shew thee that I have yet to speak on god' behalf.

36:3 I will fetch my knowledg from afar, and will ascribe
right to my maker.

36:4 for truli my word shall not be false: he that is perfect in
knowledg is with thee.

36:5 behold, god is mighty, and despiseth not any: he is mighti in
strength and wisdom.

36:6 He preserveth not the life of the wicked: but giveth right to the
poor.

36:7 He withdraweth not hi eye from the righteous: but with kings
ar they on the throne; yea, he doth establish them for ever, and they
ar exalted.

36:8 and if they be bound in fetters, and be holden in cord of
affliction; 36:9 then he sheweth them their work, and their
transgress that they have exceeded.

36:10 He openeth also their ear to discipline, and commandeth that
they return from iniquity.

36:11 If they obey and serv him, they shall spend their day in
prosperity, and their year in pleasures.

36:12 but if they obey not, they shall perish by the sword, and they
shal die without knowledge.

36:13 but the hypocrit in heart heap up wrath: they cri not when he
bindeth them.

36:14 they die in youth, and their life is among the unclean.

36:15 He delivereth the poor in hi affliction, and openeth their ears
in oppression.

36:16 even so would he have remov thee out of the strait into a
broad place, where there is no straitness; and that which should be
set on thi tabl should be full of fatness.

36:17 but thou hast fulfil the judgment of the wicked: judgment and
justic take hold on thee.

36:18 becaus there is wrath, bewar lest he take thee away with his
stroke: then a great ransom cannot deliv thee.

36:19 will he esteem thi riches? no, not gold, nor all the forc of
strength.

36:20 desir not the night, when peopl are cut off in their place.

36:21 take heed, regard not iniquity: for thi hast thou chosen rather
than affliction.

36:22 behold, god exalteth by hi power: who teacheth like him?  36:23
who hath enjoin him hi way? or who can say, thou hast wrought
iniquity?  36:24 rememb that thou magnifi hi work, which men
behold.

36:25 everi man may see it; man may behold it afar off.

36:26 behold, god is great, and we know him not, neither can the
numb of hi year be search out.

36:27 for he maketh small the drop of water: they pour down rain
accord to the vapour thereof: 36:28 which the cloud do drop and
distil upon man abundantly.

36:29 also can ani understand the spread of the clouds, or the
nois of hi tabernacle?  36:30 behold, he spreadeth hi light upon
it, and covereth the bottom of the sea.

36:31 for by them judgeth he the people; he giveth meat in abundance.

36:32 with cloud he covereth the light; and commandeth it not to
shin by the cloud that cometh betwixt.

36:33 the nois thereof sheweth concern it, the cattl also
concern the vapour.

37:1 At thi also my heart trembleth, and is move out of hi place.

37:2 hear attent the nois of hi voice, and the sound that goeth
out of hi mouth.

37:3 He directeth it under the whole heaven, and hi lightn unto
th end of the earth.

37:4 after it a voic roareth: he thundereth with the voic of his
excellency; and he will not stay them when hi voic is heard.

37:5 god thundereth marvel with hi voice; great thing doeth
he, which we cannot comprehend.

37:6 for he saith to the snow, Be thou on the earth; likewis to the
smal rain, and to the great rain of hi strength.

37:7 He sealeth up the hand of everi man; that all men may know his
work.

37:8 then the beast go into dens, and remain in their places.

37:9 out of the south cometh the whirlwind: and cold out of the north.

37:10 By the breath of god frost is given: and the breadth of the
wat is straitened.

37:11 also by water he wearieth the thick cloud: he scattereth his
bright cloud: 37:12 and it is turn round about by hi counsels: that
they may do whatsoev he commandeth them upon the face of the world
in the earth.

37:13 He causeth it to come, whether for correction, or for hi land,
or for mercy.

37:14 hearken unto this, O job: stand still, and consid the wondrous
work of god.

37:15 dost thou know when god dispos them, and caus the light of
hi cloud to shine?  37:16 dost thou know the balanc of the
clouds, the wondrou work of him which is perfect in knowledge?
37:17 how thi garment are warm, when he quieteth the earth by the
south wind?  37:18 hast thou with him spread out the sky, which is
strong, and as a molten look glass?  37:19 teach us what we shall
say unto him; for we cannot order our speech by reason of darkness.

37:20 shall it be told him that I speak? if a man speak, sure he
shal be swallow up.

37:21 and now men see not the bright light which is in the clouds: but
th wind passeth, and cleanseth them.

37:22 fair weather cometh out of the north: with god is terrible
majesty.

37:23 touch the almighty, we cannot find him out: he is excellent
in power, and in judgment, and in plenti of justice: he will not
afflict.

37:24 men do therefor fear him: he respecteth not ani that are wise
of heart.

38:1 then the lord answer job out of the whirlwind, and said, 38:2
who is thi that darkeneth counsel by word without knowledge?  38:3
gird up now thi loin like a man; for I will demand of thee, and
answ thou me.

38:4 where wast thou when I laid the foundat of the earth?
declare, if thou hast understanding.

38:5 who hath laid the measur thereof, if thou knowest? or who hath
stretch the line upon it?  38:6 whereupon are the foundations
thereof fastened? or who laid the corner stone thereof; 38:7 when the
morn star sang together, and all the son of god shout for joy?
38:8 Or who shut up the sea with doors, when it brake forth, as if it
had issu out of the womb?  38:9 when I made the cloud the garment
thereof, and thick dark a swaddlingband for it, 38:10 and brake up
for it my decre place, and set bar and doors, 38:11 and said,
hitherto shalt thou come, but no further: and here shall thi proud
wav be stayed?  38:12 hast thou command the morn sinc thy
days; and caus the dayspr to know hi place; 38:13 that it might
tak hold of the end of the earth, that the wick might be shaken
out of it?  38:14 It is turn as clay to the seal; and they stand as
a garment.

38:15 and from the wick their light is withholden, and the high arm
shal be broken.

38:16 hast thou enter into the spring of the sea? or hast thou
walk in the search of the depth?  38:17 have the gate of death been
open unto thee? or hast thou seen the door of the shadow of death?
38:18 hast thou perceiv the breadth of the earth? declar if thou
knowest it all.

38:19 where is the way where light dwelleth? and as for darkness,
wher is the place thereof, 38:20 that thou shouldest take it to the
bound thereof, and that thou shouldest know the path to the house
thereof?  38:21 knowest thou it, becaus thou wast then born? or
becaus the number of thi day is great?  38:22 hast thou enter into
th treasur of the snow? or hast thou seen the treasur of the
hail, 38:23 which I have reserv against the time of trouble, against
th day of battl and war?  38:24 By what way is the light parted,
which scattereth the east wind upon the earth?  38:25 who hath divided
a watercours for the overflow of waters, or a way for the
lightn of thunder; 38:26 To caus it to rain on the earth, where no
man is; on the wilderness, wherein there is no man; 38:27 To satisfy
th desol and wast ground; and to caus the bud of the tender herb
to spring forth?  38:28 hath the rain a father? or who hath begotten
th drop of dew?  38:29 out of whose womb came the ice? and the hoary
frost of heaven, who hath gender it?  38:30 the water are hid as
with a stone, and the face of the deep is frozen.

38:31 canst thou bind the sweet influenc of pleiades, or loos the
band of orion?  38:32 canst thou bring forth mazzaroth in hi season?
or canst thou guid arcturu with hi sons?  38:33 knowest thou the
ordin of heaven? canst thou set the dominion thereof in the
earth?  38:34 canst thou lift up thi voic to the clouds, that
abund of water may cover thee?  38:35 canst thou send lightnings,
that they may go and say unto thee, here we are?  38:36 who hath put
wisdom in the inward parts? or who hath given understand to the
heart?  38:37 who can number the cloud in wisdom? or who can stay the
bottl of heaven, 38:38 when the dust groweth into hardness, and the
clod cleav fast together?  38:39 wilt thou hunt the prey for the
lion? or fill the appetit of the young lions, 38:40 when they couch
in their dens, and abid in the covert to lie in wait?  38:41 who
provideth for the raven hi food? when hi young one cri unto god,
they wander for lack of meat.

39:1 knowest thou the time when the wild goat of the rock bring
forth? or canst thou mark when the hind do calve?  39:2 canst thou
numb the month that they fulfil? or knowest thou the time when they
br forth?  39:3 they bow themselves, they bring forth their young
ones, they cast out their sorrows.

39:4 their young one are in good liking, they grow up with corn; they
go forth, and return not unto them.

39:5 who hath sent out the wild ass free? or who hath loos the bands
of the wild ass?  39:6 whose hous I have made the wilderness, and the
barren land hi dwellings.

39:7 He scorneth the multitud of the city, neither regardeth he the
cri of the driver.

39:8 the rang of the mountain is hi pasture, and he searcheth after
everi green thing.

39:9 will the unicorn be will to serv thee, or abid by thi crib?
39:10 canst thou bind the unicorn with hi band in the furrow? or will
h harrow the valley after thee?  39:11 wilt thou trust him, because
hi strength is great? or wilt thou leav thi labour to him?  39:12
wilt thou believ him, that he will bring home thi seed, and gather it
into thi barn?  39:13 gavest thou the goodli wing unto the peacocks?
or wing and feather unto the ostrich?  39:14 which leaveth her eggs
in the earth, and warmeth them in dust, 39:15 and forgetteth that the
foot may crush them, or that the wild beast may break them.

39:16 she is harden against her young ones, as though they were not
her's: her labour is in vain without fear; 39:17 becaus god hath
depriv her of wisdom, neither hath he impart to her understanding.

39:18 what time she lifteth up herself on high, she scorneth the horse
and hi rider.

39:19 hast thou given the hors strength? hast thou cloth hi neck
with thunder?  39:20 canst thou make him afraid as a grasshopper? the
glori of hi nostril is terrible.

39:21 He paweth in the valley, and rejoiceth in hi strength: he goeth
on to meet the arm men.

39:22 He mocketh at fear, and is not affrighted; neither turneth he
back from the sword.

39:23 the quiver rattleth against him, the glitter spear and the
shield.

39:24 He swalloweth the ground with fierc and rage: neither
believeth he that it is the sound of the trumpet.

39:25 He saith among the trumpets, ha, ha; and he smelleth the battle
afar off, the thunder of the captains, and the shouting.

39:26 doth the hawk fli by thi wisdom, and stretch her wing toward
th south?  39:27 doth the eagl mount up at thi command, and make her
nest on high?  39:28 she dwelleth and abideth on the rock, upon the
crag of the rock, and the strong place.

39:29 from thenc she seeketh the prey, and her eye behold afar off.

39:30 her young one also suck up blood: and where the slain are,
ther is she.

40:1 moreov the lord answer job, and said, 40:2 shall he that
contendeth with the almighti instruct him? he that reproveth god, let
him answer it.

40:3 then job answer the lord, and said, 40:4 behold, I am vile;
what shall I answer thee? I will lay mine hand upon my mouth.

40:5 onc have I spoken; but I will not answer: yea, twice; but I will
proce no further.

40:6 then answer the lord unto job out of the whirlwind, and said,
40:7 gird up thi loin now like a man: I will demand of thee, and
declar thou unto me.

40:8 wilt thou also disannul my judgment? wilt thou condemn me, that
thou mayest be righteous?  40:9 hast thou an arm like god? or canst
thou thunder with a voic like him?  40:10 deck thyself now with
majesti and excellency; and array thyself with glori and beauty.

40:11 cast abroad the rage of thi wrath: and behold everi one that is
proud, and abas him.

40:12 look on everi one that is proud, and bring him low; and tread
down the wick in their place.

40:13 hide them in the dust together; and bind their face in secret.

40:14 then will I also confess unto thee that thine own right hand can
sav thee.

40:15 behold now behemoth, which I made with thee; he eateth grass as
an ox.

40:16 Lo now, hi strength is in hi loins, and hi forc is in the
navel of hi belly.

40:17 He moveth hi tail like a cedar: the sinew of hi stone are
wrap together.

40:18 hi bone are as strong piec of brass; hi bone are like bars
of iron.

40:19 He is the chief of the way of god: he that made him can make
hi sword to approach unto him.

40:20 sure the mountain bring him forth food, where all the beasts
of the field play.

40:21 He lieth under the shadi trees, in the covert of the reed, and
fens.

40:22 the shadi tree cover him with their shadow; the willow of the
brook compass him about.

40:23 behold, he drinketh up a river, and hasteth not: he trusteth
that he can draw up jordan into hi mouth.

40:24 He taketh it with hi eyes: hi nose pierceth through snares.

41:1 canst thou draw out leviathan with an hook? or hi tongu with a
cord which thou lettest down?  41:2 canst thou put an hook into his
nose? or bore hi jaw through with a thorn?  41:3 will he make many
suppl unto thee? will he speak soft word unto thee?  41:4
will he make a coven with thee? wilt thou take him for a servant
for ever?  41:5 wilt thou play with him as with a bird? or wilt thou
bind him for thi maidens?  41:6 shall the companion make a banquet of
him? shall they part him among the merchants?  41:7 canst thou fill
hi skin with barb irons? or hi head with fish spears?  41:8 lay
