31:27 she looketh well to the way of her household, and eateth not
th bread of idleness.

31:28 her children aris up, and call her blessed; her husband also,
and he praiseth her.

31:29 mani daughter have done virtuously, but thou excellest them
all.

31:30 favour is deceitful, and beauti is vain: but a woman that
feareth the lord, she shall be praised.

31:31 give her of the fruit of her hands; and let her own work praise
h in the gates.




ecclesiastes

or

th preacher


1:1 the word of the preacher, the son of david, king in jerusalem.

1:2 vaniti of vanities, saith the preacher, vaniti of vanities; all is
vanity.

1:3 what profit hath a man of all hi labour which he taketh under the
sun?  1:4 one gener passeth away, and anoth gener cometh:
but the earth abideth for ever.

1:5 the sun also ariseth, and the sun goeth down, and hasteth to his
plac where he arose.

1:6 the wind goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north;
it whirleth about continually, and the wind returneth again according
to hi circuits.

1:7 all the river run into the sea; yet the sea is not full; unto the
plac from whenc the river come, thither they return again.

1:8 all thing are full of labour; man cannot utter it: the eye is not
satisfi with seeing, nor the ear fill with hearing.

1:9 the thing that hath been, it is that which shall be; and that
which is done is that which shall be done: and there is no new thing
und the sun.

1:10 Is there ani thing whereof it may be said, see, thi is new? it
hath been alreadi of old time, which wa befor us.

1:11 there is no remembr of former things; neither shall there be
ani remembr of thing that are to come with those that shall come
after.

1:12 I the preacher wa king over israel in jerusalem.

1:13 and I gave my heart to seek and search out by wisdom concerning
al thing that are done under heaven: thi sore travail hath god
given to the son of man to be exercis therewith.

1:14 I have seen all the work that are done under the sun; and,
behold, all is vaniti and vexat of spirit.

1:15 that which is crook cannot be made straight: and that which is
want cannot be numbered.

1:16 I commun with mine own heart, saying, lo, I am come to great
estate, and have gotten more wisdom than all they that have been
befor me in jerusalem: yea, my heart had great experi of wisdom
and knowledge.

1:17 and I gave my heart to know wisdom, and to know mad and
folly: I perceiv that thi also is vexat of spirit.

1:18 for in much wisdom is much grief: and he that increaseth
knowledg increaseth sorrow.

2:1 I said in mine heart, Go to now, I will prove thee with mirth,
therefor enjoy pleasure: and, behold, thi also is vanity.

2:2 I said of laughter, It is mad: and of mirth, what doeth it?  2:3 i
sought in mine heart to give myself unto wine, yet acquaint mine
heart with wisdom; and to lay hold on folly, till I might see what was
that good for the son of men, which they should do under the heaven
al the day of their life.

2:4 I made me great works; I build me houses; I plant me
vineyards: 2:5 I made me garden and orchards, and I plant tree in
them of all kind of fruits: 2:6 I made me pool of water, to water
therewith the wood that bringeth forth trees: 2:7 I got me servants
and maidens, and had servant born in my house; also I had great
possess of great and small cattl abov all that were in jerusalem
befor me: 2:8 I gather me also silver and gold, and the peculiar
treasur of king and of the provinces: I gat me men singer and women
singers, and the delight of the son of men, as music instruments,
and that of all sorts.

2:9 So I wa great, and increas more than all that were befor me in
jerusalem: also my wisdom remain with me.

2:10 and whatsoev mine eye desir I kept not from them, I withheld
not my heart from ani joy; for my heart rejoic in all my labour: and
thi wa my portion of all my labour.

2:11 then I look on all the work that my hand had wrought, and on
th labour that I had labour to do: and, behold, all wa vaniti and
vex of spirit, and there wa no profit under the sun.

2:12 and I turn myself to behold wisdom, and madness, and folly: for
what can the man do that cometh after the king? even that which hath
been alreadi done.

2:13 then I saw that wisdom excelleth folly, as far as light excelleth
darkness.

2:14 the wise man' eye are in hi head; but the fool walketh in
darkness: and I myself perceiv also that one event happeneth to them
all.

2:15 then said I in my heart, As it happeneth to the fool, so it
happeneth even to me; and whi wa I then more wise? then I said in my
heart, that thi also is vanity.

2:16 for there is no remembr of the wise more than of the fool for
ever; see that which now is in the day to come shall all be
forgotten.

and how dieth the wise man? as the fool.

2:17 therefor I hate life; becaus the work that is wrought under
th sun is grievou unto me: for all is vaniti and vexat of spirit.

2:18 yea, I hate all my labour which I had taken under the sun:
becaus I should leav it unto the man that shall be after me.

2:19 and who knoweth whether he shall be a wise man or a fool? yet
shal he have rule over all my labour wherein I have laboured, and
wherein I have shew myself wise under the sun. thi is also vanity.

2:20 therefor I went about to caus my heart to despair of all the
labour which I took under the sun.

2:21 for there is a man whose labour is in wisdom, and in knowledge,
and in equity; yet to a man that hath not labour therein shall he
leav it for hi portion. thi also is vaniti and a great evil.

2:22 for what hath man of all hi labour, and of the vexat of his
heart, wherein he hath labour under the sun?  2:23 for all hi days
ar sorrows, and hi travail grief; yea, hi heart taketh not rest in
th night. thi is also vanity.

2:24 there is noth better for a man, than that he should eat and
drink, and that he should make hi soul enjoy good in hi labour. this
also I saw, that it wa from the hand of god.

2:25 for who can eat, or who els can hasten hereunto, more than i?
2:26 for god giveth to a man that is good in hi sight wisdom, and
knowledge, and joy: but to the sinner he giveth travail, to gather and
to heap up, that he may give to him that is good befor god. thi also
i vaniti and vexat of spirit.

3:1 To everi thing there is a season, and a time to everi purpose
und the heaven: 3:2 A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to
plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted; 3:3 A time to
kill, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to build
up; 3:4 A time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a
tim to dance; 3:5 A time to cast away stones, and a time to gather
ston together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from
embracing; 3:6 A time to get, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and
a time to cast away; 3:7 A time to rend, and a time to sew; a time to
keep silence, and a time to speak; 3:8 A time to love, and a time to
hate; a time of war, and a time of peace.

3:9 what profit hath he that worketh in that wherein he laboureth?
3:10 I have seen the travail, which god hath given to the son of men
to be exercis in it.

3:11 He hath made everi thing beauti in hi time: also he hath set
th world in their heart, so that no man can find out the work that
god maketh from the begin to the end.

3:12 I know that there is no good in them, but for a man to rejoice,
and to do good in hi life.

3:13 and also that everi man should eat and drink, and enjoy the good
of all hi labour, it is the gift of god.

3:14 I know that, whatsoev god doeth, it shall be for ever: nothing
can be put to it, nor ani thing taken from it: and god doeth it, that
men should fear befor him.

3:15 that which hath been is now; and that which is to be hath already
been; and god requireth that which is past.

3:16 and moreov I saw under the sun the place of judgment, that
wicked wa there; and the place of righteousness, that iniquity
wa there.

3:17 I said in mine heart, god shall judg the righteou and the
wicked: for there is a time there for everi purpos and for every
work.

3:18 I said in mine heart concern the estat of the son of men,
that god might manifest them, and that they might see that they
themselv are beasts.

3:19 for that which befalleth the son of men befalleth beasts; even
on thing befalleth them: as the one dieth, so dieth the other; yea,
they have all one breath; so that a man hath no preemin abov a
beast: for all is vanity.

3:20 all go unto one place; all are of the dust, and all turn to dust
again.

3:21 who knoweth the spirit of man that goeth upward, and the spirit
of the beast that goeth downward to the earth?  3:22 wherefor i
perc that there is noth better, than that a man should rejoice
in hi own works; for that is hi portion: for who shall bring him to
se what shall be after him?  4:1 So I returned, and consid all
th oppress that are done under the sun: and behold the tear of
such as were oppressed, and they had no comforter; and on the side of
their oppressor there wa power; but they had no comforter.

4:2 wherefor I prais the dead which are alreadi dead more than the
liv which are yet alive.

4:3 yea, better is he than both they, which hath not yet been, who
hath not seen the evil work that is done under the sun.

4:4 again, I consid all travail, and everi right work, that for
thi a man is envi of hi neighbour. thi is also vaniti and
vex of spirit.

4:5 the fool foldeth hi hand together, and eateth hi own flesh.

4:6 better is an hand with quietness, than both the hand full with
travail and vexat of spirit.

4:7 then I returned, and I saw vaniti under the sun.

4:8 there is one alone, and there is not a second; yea, he hath
neith child nor brother: yet is there no end of all hi labour;
neith is hi eye satisfi with riches; neither saith he, for whom
do I labour, and bereav my soul of good? thi is also vanity, yea, it
i a sore travail.

4:9 two are better than one; becaus they have a good reward for their
labour.

4:10 for if they fall, the one will lift up hi fellow: but woe to him
that is alon when he falleth; for he hath not anoth to help him up.

4:11 again, if two lie together, then they have heat: but how can one
b warm alone?  4:12 and if one prevail against him, two shall
withstand him; and a threefold cord is not quickli broken.

4:13 better is a poor and a wise child than an old and foolish king,
who will no more be admonished.

4:14 for out of prison he cometh to reign; wherea also he that is
born in hi kingdom becometh poor.

4:15 I consid all the live which walk under the sun, with the
second child that shall stand up in hi stead.

4:16 there is no end of all the people, even of all that have been
befor them: they also that come after shall not rejoic in him.
sur thi also is vaniti and vexat of spirit.

5:1 keep thi foot when thou goest to the hous of god, and be more
readi to hear, than to give the sacrific of fools: for they consider
not that they do evil.

5:2 Be not rash with thi mouth, and let not thine heart be hasti to
utt ani thing befor god: for god is in heaven, and thou upon earth:
therefor let thi word be few.

5:3 for a dream cometh through the multitud of business; and a fool's
voic is known by multitud of words.

5:4 when thou vowest a vow unto god, defer not to pay it; for he hath
no pleasur in fools: pay that which thou hast vowed.

5:5 better is it that thou shouldest not vow, than that thou shouldest
vow and not pay.

5:6 suffer not thi mouth to caus thi flesh to sin; neither say thou
befor the angel, that it wa an error: wherefor should god be angry
at thi voice, and destroy the work of thine hands?  5:7 for in the
multitud of dream and mani word there are also diver vanities: but
fear thou god.

5:8 If thou seest the oppress of the poor, and violent perverting
of judgment and justic in a province, marvel not at the matter: for
h that is higher than the highest regardeth; and there be higher than
they.

5:9 moreov the profit of the earth is for all: the king himself is
serv by the field.

5:10 He that loveth silver shall not be satisfi with silver; nor he
that loveth abund with increase: thi is also vanity.

5:11 when good increase, they are increas that eat them: and what
good is there to the owner thereof, save the behold of them with
their eyes?  5:12 the sleep of a labour man is sweet, whether he
eat littl or much: but the abund of the rich will not suffer him
to sleep.

5:13 there is a sore evil which I have seen under the sun, namely,
rich kept for the owner thereof to their hurt.

5:14 but those rich perish by evil travail: and he begetteth a son,
and there is noth in hi hand.

5:15 As he came forth of hi mother' womb, nake shall he return to
go as he came, and shall take noth of hi labour, which he may
carri away in hi hand.

5:16 and thi also is a sore evil, that in all point as he came, so
shal he go: and what profit hath he that hath labour for the wind?
5:17 all hi day also he eateth in darkness, and he hath much sorrow
and wrath with hi sickness.

5:18 behold that which I have seen: it is good and come for one to
eat and to drink, and to enjoy the good of all hi labour that he
taketh under the sun all the day of hi life, which god giveth him:
for it is hi portion.

5:19 everi man also to whom god hath given rich and wealth, and hath
given him power to eat thereof, and to take hi portion, and to
rejoic in hi labour; thi is the gift of god.

5:20 for he shall not much rememb the day of hi life; becaus god
answereth him in the joy of hi heart.

6:1 there is an evil which I have seen under the sun, and it is common
among men: 6:2 A man to whom god hath given riches, wealth, and
honour, so that he wanteth noth for hi soul of all that he
desireth, yet god giveth him not power to eat thereof, but a stranger
eateth it: thi is vanity, and it is an evil disease.

6:3 If a man beget an hundr children, and live mani years, so that
th day of hi year be many, and hi soul be not fill with good,
and also that he have no burial; I say, that an untim birth is
bett than he.

6:4 for he cometh in with vanity, and departeth in darkness, and his
nam shall be cover with darkness.

6:5 moreov he hath not seen the sun, nor known ani thing: thi hath
mor rest than the other.

6:6 yea, though he live a thousand year twice told, yet hath he seen
no good: do not all go to one place?  6:7 all the labour of man is for
hi mouth, and yet the appetit is not filled.

6:8 for what hath the wise more than the fool? what hath the poor,
that knoweth to walk befor the living?  6:9 better is the sight of
th eye than the wander of the desire: thi is also vaniti and
vex of spirit.

6:10 that which hath been is name already, and it is known that it is
man: neither may he contend with him that is mightier than he.

6:11 see there be mani thing that increas vanity, what is man the
better?  6:12 for who knoweth what is good for man in thi life, all
th day of hi vain life which he spendeth as a shadow? for who can
tel a man what shall be after him under the sun?  7:1 A good name is
bett than preciou ointment; and the day of death than the day of
one' birth.

7:2 It is better to go to the hous of mourning, than to go to the
hous of feasting: for that is the end of all men; and the live will
lay it to hi heart.

7:3 sorrow is better than laughter: for by the sad of the
counten the heart is made better.

7:4 the heart of the wise is in the hous of mourning; but the heart
of fool is in the hous of mirth.

7:5 It is better to hear the rebuk of the wise, than for a man to
hear the song of fools.

7:6 for as the crackl of thorn under a pot, so is the laughter of
th fool: thi also is vanity.

7:7 sure oppress maketh a wise man mad; and a gift destroyeth the
heart.

7:8 better is the end of a thing than the begin thereof: and the
pati in spirit is better than the proud in spirit.

7:9 Be not hasti in thi spirit to be angry: for anger resteth in the
bosom of fools.

7:10 say not thou, what is the caus that the former day were better
than these? for thou dost not enquir wise concern this.

7:11 wisdom is good with an inheritance: and by it there is profit to
them that see the sun.

7:12 for wisdom is a defence, and money is a defence: but the
excel of knowledg is, that wisdom giveth life to them that have
it.

7:13 consid the work of god: for who can make that straight, which
h hath made crooked?  7:14 In the day of prosper be joyful, but in
th day of advers consider: god also hath set the one over against
th other, to the end that man should find noth after him.

7:15 all thing have I seen in the day of my vanity: there is a just
man that perisheth in hi righteousness, and there is a wick man
that prolongeth hi life in hi wickedness.

7:16 Be not righteou over much; neither make thyself over wise: why
shouldest thou destroy thyself ?  7:17 Be not over much wicked,
neith be thou foolish: whi shouldest thou die befor thi time?  7:18
it is good that thou shouldest take hold of this; yea, also from this
withdraw not thine hand: for he that feareth god shall come forth of
them all.

7:19 wisdom strengtheneth the wise more than ten mighti men which are
in the city.

7:20 for there is not a just man upon earth, that doeth good, and
sinneth not.

7:21 also take no heed unto all word that are spoken; lest thou hear
thi servant curs thee: 7:22 for oftentim also thine own heart
knoweth that thou thyself likewis hast curs others.

7:23 all thi have I prove by wisdom: I said, I will be wise; but it
wa far from me.

7:24 that which is far off, and exceed deep, who can find it out?
7:25 I appli mine heart to know, and to search, and to seek out
wisdom, and the reason of things, and to know the wicked of folly,
even of foolish and madness: 7:26 and I find more bitter than
death the woman, whose heart is snare and nets, and her hand as
bands: whoso pleaseth god shall escap from her; but the sinner shall
b taken by her.

7:27 behold, thi have I found, saith the preacher, count one by
one, to find out the account: 7:28 which yet my soul seeketh, but i
find not: one man among a thousand have I found; but a woman among all
thos have I not found.

7:29 lo, thi onli have I found, that god hath made man upright; but
they have sought out mani inventions.

8:1 who is as the wise man? and who knoweth the interpret of a
thing?  a man' wisdom maketh hi face to shine, and the bold of
hi face shall be changed.

8:2 I counsel thee to keep the king' commandment, and that in regard
of the oath of god.

8:3 Be not hasti to go out of hi sight: stand not in an evil thing;
for he doeth whatsoev pleaseth him.

8:4 where the word of a king is, there is power: and who may say unto
him, what doest thou?  8:5 whoso keepeth the command shall feel no
evil thing: and a wise man' heart discerneth both time and judgment.

8:6 becaus to everi purpos there is time and judgment, therefor the
miseri of man is great upon him.

8:7 for he knoweth not that which shall be: for who can tell him when
it shall be?  8:8 there is no man that hath power over the spirit to
retain the spirit; neither hath he power in the day of death: and
ther is no discharg in that war; neither shall wicked deliver
thos that are given to it.

8:9 all thi have I seen, and appli my heart unto everi work that is
don under the sun: there is a time wherein one man ruleth over
anoth to hi own hurt.

8:10 and so I saw the wick buried, who had come and gone from the
plac of the holy, and they were forgotten in the citi where they had
so done: thi is also vanity.

8:11 becaus sentenc against an evil work is not execut speedily,
therefor the heart of the son of men is fulli set in them to do
evil.

8:12 though a sinner do evil an hundr times, and hi day be
prolonged, yet sure I know that it shall be well with them that fear
god, which fear befor him: 8:13 but it shall not be well with the
wicked, neither shall he prolong hi days, which are as a shadow;
becaus he feareth not befor god.

8:14 there is a vaniti which is done upon the earth; that there be
just men, unto whom it happeneth accord to the work of the wicked;
again, there be wick men, to whom it happeneth accord to the work
of the righteous: I said that thi also is vanity.

8:15 then I commend mirth, becaus a man hath no better thing under
th sun, than to eat, and to drink, and to be merry: for that shall
abid with him of hi labour the day of hi life, which god giveth
him under the sun.

8:16 when I appli mine heart to know wisdom, and to see the business
that is done upon the earth: (for also there is that neither day nor
night seeth sleep with hi eyes:) 8:17 then I beheld all the work of
god, that a man cannot find out the work that is done under the sun:
becaus though a man labour to seek it out, yet he shall not find it;
yea farther; though a wise man think to know it, yet shall he not be
abl to find it.

9:1 for all thi I consid in my heart even to declar all this,
that the righteous, and the wise, and their works, are in the hand of
god: no man knoweth either love or hatr by all that is befor them.

9:2 all thing come alik to all: there is one event to the righteous,
and to the wicked; to the good and to the clean, and to the unclean;
to him that sacrificeth, and to him that sacrificeth not: as is the
good, so is the sinner; and he that sweareth, as he that feareth an
oath.

9:3 thi is an evil among all thing that are done under the sun, that
ther is one event unto all: yea, also the heart of the son of men is
ful of evil, and mad is in their heart while they live, and after
that they go to the dead.

9:4 for to him that is join to all the live there is hope: for a
liv dog is better than a dead lion.

9:5 for the live know that they shall die: but the dead know not any
thing, neither have they ani more a reward; for the memori of them is
forgotten.

9:6 also their love, and their hatred, and their envy, is now
perished; neither have they ani more a portion for ever in ani thing
that is done under the sun.

9:7 Go thi way, eat thi bread with joy, and drink thi wine with a
merri heart; for god now accepteth thi works.

9:8 let thi garment be alway white; and let thi head lack no
ointment.

9:9 live joy with the wife whom thou lovest all the day of the
lif of thi vanity, which he hath given thee under the sun, all the
day of thi vanity: for that is thi portion in thi life, and in thy
labour which thou takest under the sun.

9:10 whatsoev thi hand findeth to do, do it with thi might; for
ther is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom, in the grave,
whith thou goest.

9:11 I returned, and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the
swift, nor the battl to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise,
nor yet rich to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of
skill; but time and chanc happeneth to them all.

9:12 for man also knoweth not hi time: as the fish that are taken
in an evil net, and as the bird that are caught in the snare; so are
th son of men snare in an evil time, when it falleth suddenli upon
them.

9:13 thi wisdom have I seen also under the sun, and it seem great
unto me: 9:14 there wa a littl city, and few men within it; and
ther came a great king against it, and besieg it, and built great
bulwark against it: 9:15 now there wa found in it a poor wise man,
and he by hi wisdom deliv the city; yet no man rememb that
sam poor man.

9:16 then said I, wisdom is better than strength: nevertheless the
poor man' wisdom is despised, and hi word are not heard.

9:17 the word of wise men are heard in quiet more than the cri of him
that ruleth among fools.

9:18 wisdom is better than weapon of war: but one sinner destroyeth
much good.

10:1 dead fli caus the ointment of the apothecari to send forth a
stink savour: so doth a littl folli him that is in reput for
wisdom and honour.

10:2 A wise man' heart is at hi right hand; but a fool' heart at
hi left.

10:3 yea also, when he that is a fool walketh by the way, hi wisdom
faileth him, and he saith to everi one that he is a fool.

10:4 If the spirit of the ruler rise up against thee, leav not thy
place; for yield pacifieth great offences.

10:5 there is an evil which I have seen under the sun, as an error
which proceedeth from the ruler: 10:6 folli is set in great dignity,
and the rich sit in low place.

10:7 I have seen servant upon horses, and princ walk as servants
upon the earth.

10:8 He that diggeth a pit shall fall into it; and whoso breaketh an
hedge, a serpent shall bite him.

10:9 whoso removeth stone shall be hurt therewith; and he that
cleaveth wood shall be endang thereby.

10:10 If the iron be blunt, and he do not whet the edge, then must he
put to more strength: but wisdom is profit to direct.

10:11 sure the serpent will bite without enchantment; and a babbler
i no better.

10:12 the word of a wise man' mouth are gracious; but the lip of a
fool will swallow up himself.

10:13 the begin of the word of hi mouth is foolishness: and the
end of hi talk is mischiev madness.

10:14 A fool also is full of words: a man cannot tell what shall be;
and what shall be after him, who can tell him?  10:15 the labour of
th foolish wearieth everi one of them, becaus he knoweth not how to
go to the city.

10:16 woe to thee, O land, when thi king is a child, and thi princes
eat in the morning!  10:17 bless art thou, O land, when thi king is
th son of nobles, and thi princ eat in due season, for strength,
and not for drunkenness!  10:18 By much sloth the building
decayeth; and through idl of the hand the hous droppeth
through.

10:19 A feast is made for laughter, and wine maketh merry: but money
answereth all things.

10:20 curs not the king, no not in thi thought; and curs not the
rich in thi bedchamber: for a bird of the air shall carri the voice,
and that which hath wing shall tell the matter.

11:1 cast thi bread upon the waters: for thou shalt find it after many
days.

11:2 give a portion to seven, and also to eight; for thou knowest not
what evil shall be upon the earth.

11:3 If the cloud be full of rain, they empti themselv upon the
earth: and if the tree fall toward the south, or toward the north, in
th place where the tree falleth, there it shall be.

11:4 He that observeth the wind shall not sow; and he that regardeth
th cloud shall not reap.

11:5 As thou knowest not what is the way of the spirit, nor how the
bon do grow in the womb of her that is with child: even so thou
knowest not the work of god who maketh all.

11:6 In the morn sow thi seed, and in the even withhold not
thin hand: for thou knowest not whether shall prosper, either thi or
that, or whether they both shall be alik good.

11:7 truli the light is sweet, and a pleasant thing it is for the eyes
to behold the sun: 11:8 but if a man live mani years, and rejoic in
them all; yet let him rememb the day of darkness; for they shall be
many. all that cometh is vanity.

11:9 rejoice, O young man, in thi youth; and let thi heart cheer thee
in the day of thi youth, and walk in the way of thine heart, and in
th sight of thine eyes: but know thou, that for all these thing god
wil bring thee into judgment.

11:10 therefor remov sorrow from thi heart, and put away evil from
thi flesh: for childhood and youth are vanity.

12:1 rememb now thi creator in the day of thi youth, while the evil
day come not, nor the year draw nigh, when thou shalt say, I have no
pleasur in them; 12:2 while the sun, or the light, or the moon, or
th stars, be not darkened, nor the cloud return after the rain: 12:3
in the day when the keeper of the hous shall tremble, and the strong
men shall bow themselves, and the grinder ceas becaus they are few,
and those that look out of the window be darkened, 12:4 and the doors
shal be shut in the streets, when the sound of the grind is low,
and he shall rise up at the voic of the bird, and all the daughters
of musick shall be brought low; 12:5 also when they shall be afraid of
that which is high, and fear shall be in the way, and the almond tree
shal flourish, and the grasshopp shall be a burden, and desire
shal fail: becaus man goeth to hi long home, and the mourner go
about the streets: 12:6 Or ever the silver cord be loosed, or the
golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain, or
th wheel broken at the cistern.

12:7 then shall the dust return to the earth as it was: and the spirit
shal return unto god who gave it.

12:8 vaniti of vanities, saith the preacher; all is vanity.

12:9 and moreover, becaus the preacher wa wise, he still taught the
peopl knowledge; yea, he gave good heed, and sought out, and set in
ord mani proverbs.

12:10 the preacher sought to find out accept words: and that which
wa written wa upright, even word of truth.

12:11 the word of the wise are as goads, and as nail fasten by the
mast of assemblies, which are given from one shepherd.

12:12 and further, by these, my son, be admonished: of make many
book there is no end; and much studi is a weari of the flesh.

12:13 let us hear the conclus of the whole matter: fear god, and
keep hi commandments: for thi is the whole duti of man.

12:14 for god shall bring everi work into judgment, with everi secret
thing, whether it be good, or whether it be evil.




th song of solomon


1:1 the song of songs, which is solomon's.

1:2 let him kiss me with the kiss of hi mouth: for thi love is
bett than wine.

1:3 becaus of the savour of thi good ointment thi name is as
oint pour forth, therefor do the virgin love thee.

1:4 draw me, we will run after thee: the king hath brought me into his
chambers: we will be glad and rejoic in thee, we will rememb thy
lov more than wine: the upright love thee.

1:5 I am black, but comely, O ye daughter of jerusalem, as the tents
of kedar, as the curtain of solomon.

1:6 look not upon me, becaus I am black, becaus the sun hath looked
upon me: my mother' children were angri with me; they made me the
keep of the vineyards; but mine own vineyard have I not kept.

1:7 tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth, where thou feedest, where
th makest thi flock to rest at noon: for whi should I be as one that
turneth asid by the flock of thi companions?  1:8 If thou know not,
o thou fairest among women, go thi way forth by the footstep of the
flock, and feed thi kid besid the shepherds' tents.

1:9 I have compar thee, O my love, to a compani of hors in
pharaoh' chariots.

1:10 thi cheek are come with row of jewels, thi neck with chains
of gold.

1:11 We will make thee border of gold with stud of silver.

1:12 while the king sitteth at hi table, my spikenard sendeth forth
th smell thereof.

1:13 A bundl of myrrh is my well-belov unto me; he shall lie all
night betwixt my breasts.

1:14 My belov is unto me as a cluster of camphir in the vineyards
of engedi.

1:15 behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast
doves' eyes.

1:16 behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant: also our bed is
green.

1:17 the beam of our hous are cedar, and our rafter of fir.

2:1 I am the rose of sharon, and the lili of the valleys.

2:2 As the lili among thorns, so is my love among the daughters.

2:3 As the appl tree among the tree of the wood, so is my beloved
among the sons. I sat down under hi shadow with great delight, and
hi fruit wa sweet to my taste.

2:4 He brought me to the banquet house, and hi banner over me was
love.

2:5 stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples: for I am sick of
love.

2:6 hi left hand is under my head, and hi right hand doth embrace
me.

2:7 I charg you, O ye daughter of jerusalem, by the roes, and by the
hind of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awak my love, till he
please.

2:8 the voic of my beloved! behold, he cometh leap upon the
mountains, skip upon the hills.

2:9 My belov is like a roe or a young hart: behold, he standeth
behind our wall, he looketh forth at the windows, shew himself
through the lattice.

2:10 My belov spake, and said unto me, rise up, my love, my fair
one, and come away.

2:11 for, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone; 2:12 the
flow appear on the earth; the time of the sing of bird is come,
and the voic of the turtl is heard in our land; 2:13 the fig tree
putteth forth her green figs, and the vine with the tender grape give
a good smell. arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.

2:14 O my dove, that art in the cleft of the rock, in the secret
plac of the stairs, let me see thi countenance, let me hear thy
voice; for sweet is thi voice, and thi counten is comely.

2:15 take us the foxes, the littl foxes, that spoil the vines: for
our vine have tender grapes.

2:16 My belov is mine, and I am his: he feedeth among the lilies.

2:17 until the day break, and the shadow flee away, turn, my beloved,
and be thou like a roe or a young hart upon the mountain of bether.

3:1 By night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth: I sought him,
but I found him not.

3:2 I will rise now, and go about the citi in the streets, and in the
broad way I will seek him whom my soul loveth: I sought him, but i
found him not.

3:3 the watchmen that go about the citi found me: to whom I said, saw
y him whom my soul loveth?  3:4 It wa but a littl that I passed
from them, but I found him whom my soul loveth: I held him, and would
not let him go, until I had brought him into my mother' house, and
into the chamber of her that conceiv me.

3:5 I charg you, O ye daughter of jerusalem, by the roes, and by the
hind of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awak my love, till he
please.

3:6 who is thi that cometh out of the wilder like pillar of
smoke, perfum with myrrh and frankincense, with all powder of the
merchant?  3:7 behold hi bed, which is solomon's; threescor valiant
men are about it, of the valiant of israel.

3:8 they all hold swords, be expert in war: everi man hath his
sword upon hi thigh becaus of fear in the night.

3:9 king solomon made himself a chariot of the wood of lebanon.

3:10 He made the pillar thereof of silver, the bottom thereof of
gold, the cover of it of purple, the midst thereof be pave with
love, for the daughter of jerusalem.

3:11 Go forth, O ye daughter of zion, and behold king solomon with
th crown wherewith hi mother crown him in the day of his
espousals, and in the day of the glad of hi heart.

4:1 behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast
doves' eye within thi locks: thi hair is as a flock of goats, that
appear from mount gilead.

4:2 thi teeth are like a flock of sheep that are even shorn, which
cam up from the washing; whereof everi one bear twins, and none is
barren among them.

4:3 thi lip are like a thread of scarlet, and thi speech is comely:
thi templ are like a piec of a pomegran within thi locks.

4:4 thi neck is like the tower of david build for an armoury,
whereon there hang a thousand bucklers, all shield of mighti men.

4:5 thi two breast are like two young roe that are twins, which feed
among the lilies.

4:6 until the day break, and the shadow flee away, I will get me to
th mountain of myrrh, and to the hill of frankincense.

4:7 thou art all fair, my love; there is no spot in thee.

4:8 come with me from lebanon, my spouse, with me from lebanon: look
from the top of amana, from the top of shenir and hermon, from the
lions' dens, from the mountain of the leopards.

4:9 thou hast ravish my heart, my sister, my spouse; thou hast
ravish my heart with one of thine eyes, with one chain of thi neck.

4:10 how fair is thi love, my sister, my spouse! how much better is
thi love than wine! and the smell of thine ointment than all spices!
4:11 thi lips, O my spouse, drop as the honeycomb: honey and milk are
und thi tongue; and the smell of thi garment is like the smell of
lebanon.

4:12 A garden inclos is my sister, my spouse; a spring shut up, a
fountain sealed.

4:13 thi plant are an orchard of pomegranates, with pleasant fruits;
camphire, with spikenard, 4:14 spikenard and saffron; calamu and
cinnamon, with all tree of frankincense; myrrh and aloes, with all
th chief spices: 4:15 A fountain of gardens, a well of live waters,
and stream from lebanon.

4:16 awake, O north wind; and come, thou south; blow upon my garden,
that the spice thereof may flow out. let my belov come into his
garden, and eat hi pleasant fruits.

5:1 I am come into my garden, my sister, my spouse: I have gather my
myrrh with my spice; I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey; I have
drunk my wine with my milk: eat, O friends; drink, yea, drink
abundantly, O beloved.

5:2 I sleep, but my heart waketh: it is the voic of my belov that
knocketh, saying, open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my
undefiled: for my head is fill with dew, and my lock with the drops
of the night.

5:3 I have put off my coat; how shall I put it on? I have wash my
feet; how shall I defil them?  5:4 My belov put in hi hand by the
hol of the door, and my bowel were move for him.

5:5 I rose up to open to my beloved; and my hand drop with myrrh,
and my finger with sweet smell myrrh, upon the handl of the
lock.

5:6 I open to my beloved; but my belov had withdrawn himself, and
wa gone: my soul fail when he spake: I sought him, but I could not
find him; I call him, but he gave me no answer.

5:7 the watchmen that went about the citi found me, they smote me,
they wound me; the keeper of the wall took away my veil from me.

5:8 I charg you, O daughter of jerusalem, if ye find my beloved,
that ye tell him, that I am sick of love.

5:9 what is thi belov more than anoth beloved, O thou fairest
among women? what is thi belov more than anoth beloved, that thou
dost so charg us?  5:10 My belov is white and ruddy, the chiefest
among ten thousand.

5:11 hi head is as the most fine gold, hi lock are bushy, and black
a a raven.

5:12 hi eye are as the eye of dove by the river of waters, washed
with milk, and fitli set.

5:13 hi cheek are as a bed of spices, as sweet flowers: hi lips
lik lilies, drop sweet smell myrrh.

5:14 hi hand are as gold ring set with the beryl: hi belli is as
bright ivori overlaid with sapphires.

5:15 hi leg are as pillar of marble, set upon socket of fine gold:
hi counten is as lebanon, excel as the cedars.

5:16 hi mouth is most sweet: yea, he is altogeth lovely. thi is my
beloved, and thi is my friend, O daughter of jerusalem.

6:1 whither is thi belov gone, O thou fairest among women? whither
i thi belov turn aside? that we may seek him with thee.

6:2 My belov is gone down into hi garden, to the bed of spices, to
fe in the gardens, and to gather lilies.

6:3 I am my beloved's, and my belov is mine: he feedeth among the
lilies.

6:4 thou art beautiful, O my love, as tirzah, come as jerusalem,
terr as an armi with banners.

6:5 turn away thine eye from me, for they have overcom me: thi hair
i as a flock of goat that appear from gilead.

6:6 thi teeth are as a flock of sheep which go up from the washing,
whereof everi one beareth twins, and there is not one barren among
them.

6:7 As a piec of a pomegran are thi templ within thi locks.

6:8 there are threescor queens, and fourscor concubines, and virgins
without number.

6:9 My dove, my undefil is but one; she is the onli one of her
mother, she is the choic one of her that bare her. the daughter saw
her, and bless her; yea, the queen and the concubines, and they
prais her.

6:10 who is she that looketh forth as the morning, fair as the moon,
clear as the sun, and terribl as an armi with banners?  6:11 I went
down into the garden of nut to see the fruit of the valley, and to
se whether the vine flourish and the pomegran budded.

6:12 Or ever I wa aware, my soul made me like the chariot of
amminadib.

6:13 return, return, O shulamite; return, return, that we may look
upon thee. what will ye see in the shulamite? As it were the company
of two armies.

7:1 how beauti are thi feet with shoes, O prince' daughter! the
joint of thi thigh are like jewels, the work of the hand of a
cun workman.

7:2 thi navel is like a round goblet, which wanteth not liquor: thy
belli is like an heap of wheat set about with lilies.

7:3 thi two breast are like two young roe that are twins.

7:4 thi neck is as a tower of ivory; thine eye like the fishpool in
heshbon, by the gate of bathrabbim: thi nose is as the tower of
lebanon which looketh toward damascus.

7:5 thine head upon thee is like carmel, and the hair of thine head
lik purple; the king is held in the galleries.

7:6 how fair and how pleasant art thou, O love, for delights!  7:7
thi thi statur is like to a palm tree, and thi breast to clusters
of grapes.

7:8 I said, I will go up to the palm tree, I will take hold of the
bough thereof: now also thi breast shall be as cluster of the vine,
and the smell of thi nose like apples; 7:9 and the roof of thi mouth
lik the best wine for my beloved, that goeth down sweetly, causing
th lip of those that are asleep to speak.

7:10 I am my beloved's, and hi desir is toward me.

7:11 come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field; let us lodg in
th villages.

7:12 let us get up earli to the vineyards; let us see if the vine
flourish, whether the tender grape appear, and the pomegran bud
forth: there will I give thee my loves.

7:13 the mandrak give a smell, and at our gate are all manner of
pleas fruits, new and old, which I have laid up for thee, O my
beloved.

8:1 O that thou wert as my brother, that suck the breast of my
mother!  when I should find thee without, I would kiss thee; yea, i
should not be despised.

8:2 I would lead thee, and bring thee into my mother' house, who
would instruct me: I would caus thee to drink of spice wine of the
juic of my pomegranate.

8:3 hi left hand should be under my head, and hi right hand should
embrac me.

8:4 I charg you, O daughter of jerusalem, that ye stir not up, nor
awak my love, until he please.

8:5 who is thi that cometh up from the wilderness, lean upon her
beloved? I rais thee up under the appl tree: there thi mother
brought thee forth: there she brought thee forth that bare thee.

8:6 set me as a seal upon thine heart, as a seal upon thine arm: for
lov is strong as death; jealousi is cruel as the grave: the coals
thereof are coal of fire, which hath a most vehement flame.

8:7 mani water cannot quench love, neither can the flood drown it:
if a man would give all the substanc of hi hous for love, it would
utterli be contemned.

8:8 We have a littl sister, and she hath no breasts: what shall we do
for our sister in the day when she shall be spoken for?  8:9 If she be
a wall, we will build upon her a palac of silver: and if she be a
door, we will inclos her with board of cedar.

8:10 I am a wall, and my breast like towers: then wa I in hi eyes
a one that found favour.

8:11 solomon had a vineyard at baalhamon; he let out the vineyard unto
keepers; everi one for the fruit thereof wa to bring a thousand
piec of silver.

8:12 My vineyard, which is mine, is befor me: thou, O solomon, must
hav a thousand, and those that keep the fruit thereof two hundred.

8:13 thou that dwellest in the gardens, the companion hearken to thy
voice: caus me to hear it.

8:14 make haste, my beloved, and be thou like to a roe or to a young
hart upon the mountain of spices.




th book of the prophet isaiah


1:1 the vision of isaiah the son of amoz, which he saw concerning
judah and jerusalem in the day of uzziah, jotham, ahaz, and hezekiah,
k of judah.

1:2 hear, O heavens, and give ear, O earth: for the lord hath spoken,
i have nourish and brought up children, and they have rebelled
against me.

1:3 the ox knoweth hi owner, and the ass hi master' crib: but
israel doth not know, my peopl doth not consider.

1:4 Ah sin nation, a peopl laden with iniquity, a seed of
evildoers, children that are corrupters: they have forsaken the lord,
they have provok the holi one of israel unto anger, they are gone
away backward.

1:5 whi should ye be stricken ani more? ye will revolt more and more:
th whole head is sick, and the whole heart faint.

1:6 from the sole of the foot even unto the head there is no soundness
in it; but wounds, and bruises, and putrifi sores: they have not
been closed, neither bound up, neither mollifi with ointment.

1:7 your countri is desolate, your citi are burn with fire: your
land, stranger devour it in your presence, and it is desolate, as
overthrown by strangers.

1:8 and the daughter of zion is left as a cottag in a vineyard, as a
lodg in a garden of cucumbers, as a besieg city.

1:9 except the lord of host had left unto us a veri small remnant, we
should have been as sodom, and we should have been like unto gomorrah.

1:10 hear the word of the lord, ye ruler of sodom; give ear unto the
law of our god, ye peopl of gomorrah.

1:11 To what purpos is the multitud of your sacrific unto me?
saith the lord: I am full of the burnt offer of rams, and the fat
of fed beasts; and I delight not in the blood of bullocks, or of
lambs, or of he goats.

1:12 when ye come to appear befor me, who hath requir thi at your
hand, to tread my courts?  1:13 bring no more vain oblations; incense
i an abomin unto me; the new moon and sabbaths, the call of
assemblies, I cannot away with; it is iniquity, even the solemn
meeting.

1:14 your new moon and your appoint feast my soul hateth: they are
a troubl unto me; I am weari to bear them.

1:15 and when ye spread forth your hands, I will hide mine eye from
you: yea, when ye make mani prayers, I will not hear: your hand are
ful of blood.

1:16 wash you, make you clean; put away the evil of your do from
befor mine eyes; ceas to do evil; 1:17 learn to do well; seek
judgment, reliev the oppressed, judg the fatherless, plead for the
widow.

1:18 come now, and let us reason together, saith the lord: though your
sin be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they be red
lik crimson, they shall be as wool.

1:19 If ye be will and obedient, ye shall eat the good of the land:
1:20 but if ye refus and rebel, ye shall be devour with the sword:
for the mouth of the lord hath spoken it.

1:21 how is the faith citi becom an harlot! it wa full of
judgment; righteous lodg in it; but now murderers.

1:22 thi silver is becom dross, thi wine mix with water: 1:23 thy
princ are rebellious, and companion of thieves: everi one loveth
gifts, and followeth after rewards: they judg not the fatherless,
neith doth the caus of the widow come unto them.

1:24 therefor saith the lord, the lord of hosts, the mighti one of
israel, ah, I will eas me of mine adversaries, and aveng me of mine
enemies: 1:25 and I will turn my hand upon thee, and pure purg away
thi dross, and take away all thi tin: 1:26 and I will restor thy
judg as at the first, and thi counsellor as at the beginning:
afterward thou shalt be called, the citi of righteousness, the
faith city.

1:27 zion shall be redeem with judgment, and her convert with
righteousness.

1:28 and the destruct of the transgressor and of the sinner shall
b together, and they that forsak the lord shall be consumed.

1:29 for they shall be asham of the oak which ye have desired, and
y shall be confound for the garden that ye have chosen.

1:30 for ye shall be as an oak whose leaf fadeth, and as a garden that
hath no water.

1:31 and the strong shall be as tow, and the maker of it as a spark,
and they shall both burn together, and none shall quench them.

2:1 the word that isaiah the son of amoz saw concern judah and
jerusalem.

2:2 and it shall come to pass in the last days, that the mountain of
th lord' hous shall be establish in the top of the mountains, and
shal be exalt abov the hills; and all nation shall flow unto it.

2:3 and mani peopl shall go and say, come ye, and let us go up to the
mountain of the lord, to the hous of the god of jacob; and he will
teach us of hi ways, and we will walk in hi paths: for out of zion
shal go forth the law, and the word of the lord from jerusalem.

2:4 and he shall judg among the nations, and shall rebuk many
people: and they shall beat their sword into plowshares, and their
spear into pruninghooks: nation shall not lift up sword against
nation, neither shall they learn war ani more.

2:5 O hous of jacob, come ye, and let us walk in the light of the
lord.

2:6 therefor thou hast forsaken thi peopl the hous of jacob,
becaus they be replenish from the east, and are soothsay like
th philistines, and they pleas themselv in the children of
strangers.

2:7 their land also is full of silver and gold, neither is there any
end of their treasures; their land is also full of horses, neither is
ther ani end of their chariots: 2:8 their land also is full of idols;
they worship the work of their own hands, that which their own fingers
hav made: 2:9 and the mean man boweth down, and the great man
humbleth himself: therefor forgiv them not.

2:10 enter into the rock, and hide thee in the dust, for fear of the
lord, and for the glori of hi majesty.

2:11 the lofti look of man shall be humbled, and the haughti of
men shall be bow down, and the lord alon shall be exalt in that
day.

2:12 for the day of the lord of host shall be upon everi one that is
proud and lofty, and upon everi one that is lift up; and he shall be
brought low: 2:13 and upon all the cedar of lebanon, that are high
and lift up, and upon all the oak of bashan, 2:14 and upon all the
high mountains, and upon all the hill that are lift up, 2:15 and
upon everi high tower, and upon everi fenc wall, 2:16 and upon all
th ship of tarshish, and upon all pleasant pictures.

2:17 and the lofti of man shall be bow down, and the haughtiness
of men shall be made low: and the lord alon shall be exalt in that
day.

2:18 and the idol he shall utterli abolish.

2:19 and they shall go into the hole of the rocks, and into the caves
of the earth, for fear of the lord, and for the glori of hi majesty,
when he ariseth to shake terribl the earth.

2:20 In that day a man shall cast hi idol of silver, and hi idols
of gold, which they made each one for himself to worship, to the moles
and to the bats; 2:21 To go into the cleft of the rocks, and into the
top of the rag rocks, for fear of the lord, and for the glori of
hi majesty, when he ariseth to shake terribl the earth.

2:22 ceas ye from man, whose breath is in hi nostrils: for wherein
i he to be account of ?  3:1 for, behold, the lord, the lord of
hosts, doth take away from jerusalem and from judah the stay and the
staff, the whole stay of bread, and the whole stay of water.

3:2 the mighti man, and the man of war, the judge, and the prophet,
and the prudent, and the ancient, 3:3 the captain of fifty, and the
honour man, and the counsellor, and the cun artificer, and the
eloqu orator.

3:4 and I will give children to be their princes, and babe shall rule
ov them.

3:5 and the peopl shall be oppressed, everi one by another, and every
on by hi neighbour: the child shall behav himself proudli against
th ancient, and the base against the honourable.

3:6 when a man shall take hold of hi brother of the hous of his
father, saying, thou hast clothing, be thou our ruler, and let this
ruin be under thi hand: 3:7 In that day shall he swear, saying, I will
not be an healer; for in my hous is neither bread nor clothing: make
m not a ruler of the people.

3:8 for jerusalem is ruined, and judah is fallen: becaus their tongue
and their do are against the lord, to provok the eye of his
glory.

3:9 the shew of their counten doth wit against them; and they
declar their sin as sodom, they hide it not. woe unto their soul! for
they have reward evil unto themselves.

3:10 say ye to the righteous, that it shall be well with him: for they
shal eat the fruit of their doings.

3:11 woe unto the wicked! it shall be ill with him: for the reward of
hi hand shall be given him.

3:12 As for my people, children are their oppressors, and women rule
ov them. O my people, they which lead thee caus thee to err, and
destroy the way of thi paths.

3:13 the lord standeth up to plead, and standeth to judg the people.

3:14 the lord will enter into judgment with the ancient of his
people, and the princ thereof: for ye have eaten up the vineyard;
th spoil of the poor is in your houses.

3:15 what mean ye that ye beat my peopl to pieces, and grind the
fac of the poor? saith the lord god of hosts.

3:16 moreov the lord saith, becaus the daughter of zion are
haughty, and walk with stretch forth neck and wanton eyes, walking
and minc as they go, and make a tinkl with their feet: 3:17
therefor the lord will smite with a scab the crown of the head of the
daught of zion, and the lord will discov their secret parts.

3:18 In that day the lord will take away the braveri of their tinkling
orna about their feet, and their cauls, and their round tires
lik the moon, 3:19 the chains, and the bracelets, and the mufflers,
3:20 the bonnets, and the ornament of the legs, and the headbands,
and the tablets, and the earrings, 3:21 the rings, and nose jewels,
3:22 the changeabl suit of apparel, and the mantles, and the
wimples, and the crisp pins, 3:23 the glasses, and the fine linen,
and the hoods, and the vails.

3:24 and it shall come to pass, that instead of sweet smell there
shal be stink; and instead of a girdl a rent; and instead of well
set hair baldness; and instead of a stomach a gird of sackcloth;
and burn instead of beauty.

3:25 thi men shall fall by the sword, and thi mighti in the war.

3:26 and her gate shall lament and mourn; and she be desolate
shal sit upon the ground.

4:1 and in that day seven women shall take hold of one man, saying, we
wil eat our own bread, and wear our own apparel: onli let us be
cal by thi name, to take away our reproach.

4:2 In that day shall the branch of the lord be beauti and
glorious, and the fruit of the earth shall be excel and come for
them that are escap of israel.

4:3 and it shall come to pass, that he that is left in zion, and he
that remaineth in jerusalem, shall be call holy, even everi one that
i written among the live in jerusalem: 4:4 when the lord shall have
wash away the filth of the daughter of zion, and shall have purged
th blood of jerusalem from the midst thereof by the spirit of
judgment, and by the spirit of burning.

4:5 and the lord will creat upon everi dwell place of mount zion,
and upon her assemblies, a cloud and smoke by day, and the shine of
a flame fire by night: for upon all the glori shall be a defence.

4:6 and there shall be a tabernacl for a shadow in the day time from
th heat, and for a place of refuge, and for a covert from storm and
from rain.

5:1 now will I sing to my wellbelov a song of my belov touching
hi vineyard. My wellbelov hath a vineyard in a veri fruit hill:
5:2 and he fenc it, and gather out the stone thereof, and planted
it with the choicest vine, and built a tower in the midst of it, and
also made a winepress therein: and he look that it should bring
forth grapes, and it brought forth wild grapes.

5:3 and now, O inhabit of jerusalem, and men of judah, judge, i
pray you, betwixt me and my vineyard.

5:4 what could have been done more to my vineyard, that I have not
don in it? wherefore, when I look that it should bring forth
grapes, brought it forth wild grapes?  5:5 and now go to; I will tell
you what I will do to my vineyard: I will take away the hedg thereof,
and it shall be eaten up; and break down the wall thereof, and it
shal be trodden down: 5:6 and I will lay it waste: it shall not be
pruned, nor digged; but there shall come up brier and thorns: I will
also command the cloud that they rain no rain upon it.

5:7 for the vineyard of the lord of host is the hous of israel, and
th men of judah hi pleasant plant: and he look for judgment, but
behold oppression; for righteousness, but behold a cry.

5:8 woe unto them that join hous to house, that lay field to field,
til there be no place, that they may be place alon in the midst of
th earth!  5:9 In mine ear said the lord of hosts, Of a truth many
hous shall be desolate, even great and fair, without inhabitant.

5:10 yea, ten acr of vineyard shall yield one bath, and the seed of
an homer shall yield an ephah.

5:11 woe unto them that rise up earli in the morning, that they may
follow strong drink; that continu until night, till wine inflame
them!  5:12 and the harp, and the viol, the tabret, and pipe, and
wine, are in their feasts: but they regard not the work of the lord,
neith consid the oper of hi hands.

5:13 therefor my peopl are gone into captivity, becaus they have no
knowledge: and their honour men are famished, and their multitude
dri up with thirst.

5:14 therefor hell hath enlarg herself, and open her mouth
without measure: and their glory, and their multitude, and their pomp,
and he that rejoiceth, shall descend into it.

5:15 and the mean man shall be brought down, and the mighti man shall
b humbled, and the eye of the lofti shall be humbled: 5:16 but the
lord of host shall be exalt in judgment, and god that is holi shall
b sanctifi in righteousness.

5:17 then shall the lamb feed after their manner, and the waste
plac of the fat one shall stranger eat.

5:18 woe unto them that draw iniqu with cord of vanity, and sin as
it were with a cart rope: 5:19 that say, let him make speed, and
hasten hi work, that we may see it: and let the counsel of the holy
on of israel draw nigh and come, that we may know it!  5:20 woe unto
them that call evil good, and good evil; that put dark for light,
and light for darkness; that put bitter for sweet, and sweet for
bitter!  5:21 woe unto them that are wise in their own eyes, and
prud in their own sight!  5:22 woe unto them that are mighti to
drink wine, and men of strength to mingl strong drink: 5:23 which
justifi the wick for reward, and take away the righteous of the
right from him!  5:24 therefor as the fire devoureth the stubble,
and the flame consumeth the chaff, so their root shall be as
rottenness, and their blossom shall go up as dust: becaus they have
cast away the law of the lord of hosts, and despis the word of the
holi one of israel.

5:25 therefor is the anger of the lord kindl against hi people,
and he hath stretch forth hi hand against them, and hath smitten
them: and the hill did tremble, and their carcas were torn in the
midst of the streets.

for all thi hi anger is not turn away, but hi hand is stretched
out still.

5:26 and he will lift up an ensign to the nation from far, and will
hiss unto them from the end of the earth: and, behold, they shall come
with speed swiftly: 5:27 none shall be weari nor stumbl among them;
non shall slumber nor sleep; neither shall the girdl of their loins
b loosed, nor the latchet of their shoe be broken: 5:28 whose arrows
ar sharp, and all their bow bent, their horses' hoof shall be
count like flint, and their wheel like a whirlwind: 5:29 their
roar shall be like a lion, they shall roar like young lions: yea,
they shall roar, and lay hold of the prey, and shall carri it away
safe, and none shall deliv it.

5:30 and in that day they shall roar against them like the roar of
th sea: and if one look unto the land, behold dark and sorrow,
and the light is darken in the heaven thereof.

6:1 In the year that king uzziah die I saw also the lord sit upon
a throne, high and lift up, and hi train fill the temple.

6:2 abov it stood the seraphims: each one had six wings; with twain
h cover hi face, and with twain he cover hi feet, and with
twain he did fly.

6:3 and one cri unto another, and said, holy, holy, holy, is the
lord of hosts: the whole earth is full of hi glory.

6:4 and the post of the door move at the voic of him that cried,
and the hous wa fill with smoke.

6:5 then said I, woe is me! for I am undone; becaus I am a man of
unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a peopl of unclean lips:
for mine eye have seen the king, the lord of hosts.

6:6 then flew one of the seraphim unto me, have a live coal in his
hand, which he had taken with the tong from off the altar: 6:7 and he
laid it upon my mouth, and said, lo, thi hath touch thi lips; and
thin iniqu is taken away, and thi sin purged.

6:8 also I heard the voic of the lord, saying, whom shall I send, and
who will go for us? then said I, here am I; send me.

6:9 and he said, go, and tell thi people, hear ye indeed, but
understand not; and see ye indeed, but perceiv not.

6:10 make the heart of thi peopl fat, and make their ear heavy, and
shut their eyes; lest they see with their eyes, and hear with their
ears, and understand with their heart, and convert, and be healed.

6:11 then said I, lord, how long? and he answered, until the citi be
wast without inhabitant, and the hous without man, and the land be
utterli desolate, 6:12 and the lord have remov men far away, and
ther be a great forsak in the midst of the land.

6:13 but yet in it shall be a tenth, and it shall return, and shall be
eaten: as a teil tree, and as an oak, whose substanc is in them, when
they cast their leaves: so the holi seed shall be the substance
thereof.

7:1 and it came to pass in the day of ahaz the son of jotham, the son
of uzziah, king of judah, that rezin the king of syria, and pekah the
son of remaliah, king of israel, went up toward jerusalem to war
against it, but could not prevail against it.

7:2 and it wa told the hous of david, saying, syria is confederate
with ephraim. and hi heart wa moved, and the heart of hi people, as
th tree of the wood are move with the wind.

7:3 then said the lord unto isaiah, Go forth now to meet ahaz, thou,
and shearjashub thi son, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool
in the highway of the fuller' field; 7:4 and say unto him, take heed,
and be quiet; fear not, neither be faintheart for the two tail of
thes smoke firebrands, for the fierc anger of rezin with syria,
and of the son of remaliah.

7:5 becaus syria, ephraim, and the son of remaliah, have taken evil
counsel against thee, saying, 7:6 let us go up against judah, and vex
it, and let us make a breach therein for us, and set a king in the
midst of it, even the son of tabeal: 7:7 thu saith the lord god, it
shal not stand, neither shall it come to pass.

7:8 for the head of syria is damascus, and the head of damascu is
rezin; and within threescor and five year shall ephraim be broken,
that it be not a people.

7:9 and the head of ephraim is samaria, and the head of samaria is
remaliah' son. If ye will not believe, sure ye shall not be
established.

7:10 moreov the lord spake again unto ahaz, saying, 7:11 ask thee a
sign of the lord thi god; ask it either in the depth, or in the height
above.

7:12 but ahaz said, I will not ask, neither will I tempt the lord.

7:13 and he said, hear ye now, O hous of david; Is it a small thing
for you to weari men, but will ye weari my god also?  7:14 therefore
th lord himself shall give you a sign; behold, a virgin shall
conceive, and bear a son, and shall call hi name immanuel.

7:15 butter and honey shall he eat, that he may know to refus the
evil, and choos the good.

7:16 for befor the child shall know to refus the evil, and choose
th good, the land that thou abhorrest shall be forsaken of both her
kings.

7:17 the lord shall bring upon thee, and upon thi people, and upon thy
father' house, day that have not come, from the day that ephraim
depart from judah; even the king of assyria.

7:18 and it shall come to pass in that day, that the lord shall hiss
for the fli that is in the uttermost part of the river of egypt, and
for the bee that is in the land of assyria.

7:19 and they shall come, and shall rest all of them in the desolate
valleys, and in the hole of the rocks, and upon all thorns, and upon
al bushes.

7:20 In the same day shall the lord shave with a razor that is hired,
namely, by them beyond the river, by the king of assyria, the head,
and the hair of the feet: and it shall also consum the beard.

7:21 and it shall come to pass in that day, that a man shall nourish a
young cow, and two sheep; 7:22 and it shall come to pass, for the
abund of milk that they shall give he shall eat butter: for butter
and honey shall everi one eat that is left in the land.

7:23 and it shall come to pass in that day, that everi place shall be,
wher there were a thousand vine at a thousand silverlings, it shall
even be for brier and thorns.

7:24 with arrow and with bow shall men come thither; becaus all the
land shall becom brier and thorns.

7:25 and on all hill that shall be dig with the mattock, there
shal not come thither the fear of brier and thorns: but it shall be
for the send forth of oxen, and for the tread of lesser cattle.

8:1 moreov the lord said unto me, take thee a great roll, and write
in it with a man' pen concern mahershalalhashbaz.

8:2 and I took unto me faith wit to record, uriah the priest,
and zechariah the son of jeberechiah.

8:3 and I went unto the prophetess; and she conceived, and bare a son.

then said the lord to me, call hi name mahershalalhashbaz.

8:4 for befor the child shall have knowledg to cry, My father, and
mi mother, the rich of damascu and the spoil of samaria shall be
taken away befor the king of assyria.

8:5 the lord spake also unto me again, saying, 8:6 forasmuch as this
peopl refuseth the water of shiloah that go softly, and rejoic in
rezin and remaliah' son; 8:7 now therefore, behold, the lord bringeth
up upon them the water of the river, strong and many, even the king
of assyria, and all hi glory: and he shall come up over all his
channels, and go over all hi banks: 8:8 and he shall pass through
judah; he shall overflow and go over, he shall reach even to the neck;
and the stretch out of hi wing shall fill the breadth of thy
land, O immanuel.

8:9 associ yourselves, O ye people, and ye shall be broken in
pieces; and give ear, all ye of far countries: gird yourselves, and ye
shal be broken in pieces; gird yourselves, and ye shall be broken in
pieces.

8:10 take counsel together, and it shall come to nought; speak the
word, and it shall not stand: for god is with us.

8:11 for the lord spake thu to me with a strong hand, and instructed
m that I should not walk in the way of thi people, saying, 8:12 say
y not, A confederacy, to all them to whom thi peopl shall say, a
confederacy; neither fear ye their fear, nor be afraid.

8:13 sanctifi the lord of host himself; and let him be your fear, and
let him be your dread.

8:14 and he shall be for a sanctuary; but for a stone of stumbl and
for a rock of offenc to both the hous of israel, for a gin and for
a snare to the inhabit of jerusalem.

8:15 and mani among them shall stumble, and fall, and be broken, and
b snared, and be taken.

8:16 bind up the testimony, seal the law among my disciples.

8:17 and I will wait upon the lord, that hideth hi face from the
hous of jacob, and I will look for him.

8:18 behold, I and the children whom the lord hath given me are for
sign and for wonder in israel from the lord of hosts, which dwelleth
in mount zion.

8:19 and when they shall say unto you, seek unto them that have
familiar spirits, and unto wizard that peep, and that mutter: should
not a peopl seek unto their god? for the live to the dead?  8:20 to
th law and to the testimony: if they speak not accord to this
word, it is becaus there is no light in them.

8:21 and they shall pass through it, hardli bestead and hungry: and it
shal come to pass, that when they shall be hungry, they shall fret
themselves, and curs their king and their god, and look upward.

8:22 and they shall look unto the earth; and behold troubl and
darkness, dim of anguish; and they shall be driven to darkness.

9:1 nevertheless the dim shall not be such as wa in her vexation,
when at the first he lightli afflict the land of zebulun and the
land of naphtali, and afterward did more grievous afflict her by the
way of the sea, beyond jordan, in galile of the nations.

9:2 the peopl that walk in dark have seen a great light: they
that dwell in the land of the shadow of death, upon them hath the
light shined.

9:3 thou hast multipli the nation, and not increas the joy: they
joy befor thee accord to the joy in harvest, and as men rejoice
when they divid the spoil.

9:4 for thou hast broken the yoke of hi burden, and the staff of his
shoulder, the rod of hi oppressor, as in the day of midian.

9:5 for everi battl of the warrior is with confus noise, and
gar roll in blood; but thi shall be with burn and fuel of
fire.

9:6 for unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given: and the
govern shall be upon hi shoulder: and hi name shall be called
wonderful, counsellor, the mighti god, the everlast father, the
princ of peace.

9:7 Of the increas of hi govern and peac there shall be no end,
upon the throne of david, and upon hi kingdom, to order it, and to
establish it with judgment and with justic from henceforth even for
ever. the zeal of the lord of host will perform this.

9:8 the lord sent a word into jacob, and it hath light upon israel.

9:9 and all the peopl shall know, even ephraim and the inhabit of
samaria, that say in the pride and stout of heart, 9:10 the bricks
ar fallen down, but we will build with hewn stones: the sycomor are
cut down, but we will chang them into cedars.

9:11 therefor the lord shall set up the adversari of rezin against
him, and join hi enemi together; 9:12 the syrian before, and the
philistin behind; and they shall devour israel with open mouth. for
al thi hi anger is not turn away, but hi hand is stretch out
still.

9:13 for the peopl turneth not unto him that smiteth them, neither do
they seek the lord of hosts.

9:14 therefor the lord will cut off from israel head and tail, branch
and rush, in one day.

9:15 the ancient and honourable, he is the head; and the prophet that
teacheth lies, he is the tail.

9:16 for the leader of thi peopl caus them to err; and they that
ar led of them are destroyed.

9:17 therefor the lord shall have no joy in their young men, neither
shal have merci on their fatherless and widows: for everi one is an
hypocrit and an evildoer, and everi mouth speaketh folly. for all
thi hi anger is not turn away, but hi hand is stretch out
still.

9:18 for wicked burneth as the fire: it shall devour the briers
and thorns, and shall kindl in the thicket of the forest, and they
shal mount up like the lift up of smoke.

9:19 through the wrath of the lord of host is the land darkened, and
th peopl shall be as the fuel of the fire: no man shall spare his
brother.

9:20 and he shall snatch on the right hand, and be hungry; and he
shal eat on the left hand, and they shall not be satisfied: they
shal eat everi man the flesh of hi own arm: 9:21 manasseh, ephraim;
and ephraim, manasseh: and they togeth shall be against judah. for
al thi hi anger is not turn away, but hi hand is stretch out
still.

10:1 woe unto them that decre unright decrees, and that write
griev which they have prescribed; 10:2 To turn asid the needy
from judgment, and to take away the right from the poor of my people,
that widow may be their prey, and that they may rob the fatherless!
10:3 and what will ye do in the day of visitation, and in the
desol which shall come from far? to whom will ye flee for help?
and where will ye leav your glory?  10:4 without me they shall bow
down under the prisoners, and they shall fall under the slain. for all
thi hi anger is not turn away, but hi hand is stretch out
still.

10:5 O assyrian, the rod of mine anger, and the staff in their hand is
min indignation.

10:6 I will send him against an hypocrit nation, and against the
peopl of my wrath will I give him a charge, to take the spoil, and to
tak the prey, and to tread them down like the mire of the streets.

10:7 howbeit he meaneth not so, neither doth hi heart think so; but
it is in hi heart to destroy and cut off nation not a few.

10:8 for he saith, are not my princ altogeth kings?  10:9 Is not
calno as carchemish? is not hamath as arpad? is not samaria as
damascus?  10:10 As my hand hath found the kingdom of the idols, and
whos graven imag did excel them of jerusalem and of samaria; 10:11
shall I not, as I have done unto samaria and her idols, so do to
jerusalem and her idols?  10:12 wherefor it shall come to pass, that
when the lord hath perform hi whole work upon mount zion and on
jerusalem, I will punish the fruit of the stout heart of the king of
assyria, and the glori of hi high looks.

10:13 for he saith, By the strength of my hand I have done it, and by
mi wisdom; for I am prudent: and I have remov the bound of the
people, and have rob their treasures, and I have put down the
inhabit like a valiant man: 10:14 and my hand hath found as a nest
th rich of the people: and as one gathereth egg that are left,
hav I gather all the earth; and there wa none that move the wing,
or open the mouth, or peeped.

10:15 shall the axe boast itself against him that heweth therewith? or
shal the saw magnifi itself against him that shaketh it? as if the
rod should shake itself against them that lift it up, or as if the
staff should lift up itself, as if it were no wood.

10:16 therefor shall the lord, the lord of hosts, send among hi fat
on leanness; and under hi glori he shall kindl a burn like the
burn of a fire.

10:17 and the light of israel shall be for a fire, and hi holi one
for a flame: and it shall burn and devour hi thorn and hi brier in
on day; 10:18 and shall consum the glori of hi forest, and of his
fruit field, both soul and body: and they shall be as when a
standard-bear fainteth.

10:19 and the rest of the tree of hi forest shall be few, that a
child may write them.

10:20 and it shall come to pass in that day, that the remnant of
israel, and such as are escap of the hous of jacob, shall no more
again stay upon him that smote them; but shall stay upon the lord, the
holi one of israel, in truth.

10:21 the remnant shall return, even the remnant of jacob, unto the
mighti god.

10:22 for though thi peopl israel be as the sand of the sea, yet a
remn of them shall return: the consumpt decre shall overflow
with righteousness.

10:23 for the lord god of host shall make a consumption, even
determined, in the midst of all the land.

10:24 therefor thu saith the lord god of hosts, O my peopl that
dwellest in zion, be not afraid of the assyrian: he shall smite thee
with a rod, and shall lift up hi staff against thee, after the manner
of egypt.

10:25 for yet a veri littl while, and the indign shall cease,
and mine anger in their destruction.

10:26 and the lord of host shall stir up a scourg for him according
to the slaughter of midian at the rock of oreb: and as hi rod was
upon the sea, so shall he lift it up after the manner of egypt.

10:27 and it shall come to pass in that day, that hi burden shall be
taken away from off thi shoulder, and hi yoke from off thi neck, and
th yoke shall be destroy becaus of the anointing.

10:28 He is come to aiath, he is pass to migron; at michmash he hath
laid up hi carriages: 10:29 they are gone over the passage: they have
taken up their lodg at geba; ramah is afraid; gibeah of saul is
fled.

10:30 lift up thi voice, O daughter of gallim: caus it to be heard
unto laish, O poor anathoth.

10:31 madmenah is removed; the inhabit of gebim gather themselves
to flee.

10:32 As yet shall he remain at nob that day: he shall shake hi hand
against the mount of the daughter of zion, the hill of jerusalem.

10:33 behold, the lord, the lord of hosts, shall lop the bough with
terror: and the high one of statur shall be hewn down, and the
haughti shall be humbled.

10:34 and he shall cut down the thicket of the forest with iron, and
lebanon shall fall by a mighti one.

11:1 and there shall come forth a rod out of the stem of jesse, and a
branch shall grow out of hi roots: 11:2 and the spirit of the lord
shal rest upon him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the
spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledg and of the fear
of the lord; 11:3 and shall make him of quick understand in the
fear of the lord: and he shall not judg after the sight of hi eyes,
neith reprov after the hear of hi ears: 11:4 but with
right shall he judg the poor, and reprov with equiti for the
meek of the earth: and he shall smite the earth: with the rod of his
mouth, and with the breath of hi lip shall he slay the wicked.

11:5 and righteous shall be the girdl of hi loins, and
faith the girdl of hi reins.

11:6 the wolf also shall dwell with the lamb, and the leopard shall
li down with the kid; and the calf and the young lion and the fatling
together; and a littl child shall lead them.

11:7 and the cow and the bear shall feed; their young one shall lie
down together: and the lion shall eat straw like the ox.

11:8 and the suck child shall play on the hole of the asp, and the
wean child shall put hi hand on the cockatrice' den.

11:9 they shall not hurt nor destroy in all my holi mountain: for the
earth shall be full of the knowledg of the lord, as the water cover
th sea.

11:10 and in that day there shall be a root of jesse, which shall
stand for an ensign of the people; to it shall the gentil seek: and
hi rest shall be glorious.

11:11 and it shall come to pass in that day, that the lord shall set
hi hand again the second time to recov the remnant of hi people,
which shall be left, from assyria, and from egypt, and from pathros,
and from cush, and from elam, and from shinar, and from hamath, and
from the island of the sea.

11:12 and he shall set up an ensign for the nations, and shall
assembl the outcast of israel, and gather togeth the dispers of
judah from the four corner of the earth.

11:13 the envi also of ephraim shall depart, and the adversari of
judah shall be cut off: ephraim shall not envi judah, and judah shall
not vex ephraim.

11:14 but they shall fli upon the shoulder of the philistin toward
th west; they shall spoil them of the east together: they shall lay
their hand upon edom and moab; and the children of ammon shall obey
them.

11:15 and the lord shall utterli destroy the tongu of the egyptian
sea; and with hi mighti wind shall he shake hi hand over the river,
and shall smite it in the seven streams, and make men go over dryshod.

11:16 and there shall be an highway for the remnant of hi people,
which shall be left, from assyria; like as it wa to israel in the day
that he came up out of the land of egypt.

12:1 and in that day thou shalt say, O lord, I will prais thee:
though thou wast angri with me, thine anger is turn away, and thou
comfortedst me.

12:2 behold, god is my salvation; I will trust, and not be afraid: for
th lord jehovah is my strength and my song; he also is becom my
salvation.

12:3 therefor with joy shall ye draw water out of the well of
salvation.

12:4 and in that day shall ye say, prais the lord, call upon his
name, declar hi do among the people, make mention that hi name
i exalted.

12:5 sing unto the lord; for he hath done excel things: thi is
known in all the earth.

12:6 cri out and shout, thou inhabit of zion: for great is the holy
on of israel in the midst of thee.

13:1 the burden of babylon, which isaiah the son of amoz did see.

13:2 lift ye up a banner upon the high mountain, exalt the voic unto
them, shake the hand, that they may go into the gate of the nobles.

13:3 I have command my sanctifi ones, I have also call my mighty
on for mine anger, even them that rejoic in my highness.

13:4 the nois of a multitud in the mountains, like as of a great
people; a tumultu nois of the kingdom of nation gathered
together: the lord of host mustereth the host of the battle.

13:5 they come from a far country, from the end of heaven, even the
lord, and the weapon of hi indignation, to destroy the whole land.

13:6 howl ye; for the day of the lord is at hand; it shall come as a
destruct from the almighty.

13:7 therefor shall all hand be faint, and everi man' heart shall
melt: 13:8 and they shall be afraid: pang and sorrow shall take hold
of them; they shall be in pain as a woman that travaileth: they shall
b amaz one at another; their face shall be as flames.

13:9 behold, the day of the lord cometh, cruel both with wrath and
fierc anger, to lay the land desolate: and he shall destroy the
sinn thereof out of it.

13:10 for the star of heaven and the constel thereof shall not
